{"uri": "8242071365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:20:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:20:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:19:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.wfae.org/sports/2024-07-24/paris-olympics-what-to-watch-for", "title": "Paris Olympics: What to watch for", "body": "NPR is in Paris for the 2024 Summer Olympics. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nAfter COVID-19 pandemic restrictions kept spectators away for the last two Olympic Games (in Beijing and Tokyo), the French capital has prepared to welcome back crowds with a splash: the public will be treated to a unique opening ceremony on the iconic River Seine.\n\nThe outdoor ceremony -- set to be the largest one yet, measured by audience and geographical sprawl -- kicks off 16 days of sporting events held across the city and beyond.\n\nOutside of Paris, the historic Palace of Versailles will host equestrian events, while surfing will take place some 10,000 miles away in Teahupo'o, Tahiti.\n\nContinuing its streak of domination at the Summer Games, the United States is expected to collect the most medals in Paris, followed by China, Great Britain, France and then Australia. Russia, meanwhile -- typically a top contender -- is sending a very small number of athletes to Paris following consequences related to their country's doping and its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nHere's what else to know ahead of the Games before the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nClose to 100 boats carrying more than 10,000 athletes and performers will glide down a 3.7-mile stretch of the River Seine during the opening ceremony on July 26. It's the first time in the history of the modern Olympics that's being held outside of a stadium, officials say.\n\nThe open-air event is expected to draw some 300,000 spectators -- most of whom will pay no admission fee to watch the parade from the river's upper embankments.\n\nThe parade will travel east to west, starting at Austerlitz Bridge, and then pass by major landmarks and event venues like the Grand Palais. The parade is set to end at the Pont d'I\u00e9na bridge before a finale show at the Trocad\u00e9ro opposite the Eiffel Tower.\n\nTony Estanguet, president of the Paris Games organizing committee, described the vision for the ceremony when the plan was announced in 2021.\n\n\"The entire city has been turned into a vast Olympic stadium. The Seine represents the track, and the quays the spectators' stands,\" Estanguet said.\n\nThe parade's route also offers a sightseeing tour of some of the temporary sports venues, including an outdoor arena abutting the Eiffel Tower where beach volleyball games will take place.\n\nThere's also the matter of the Seine as a competition venue. In the run-up to the games, a question has plagued officials: Will the Seine be swimmable in time for the Olympics? The sewage-polluted waters have been a hurdle to the city's ambitious goal to hold the swim leg of the triathlon in the famous river where swimming has been historically banned.\n\nRecent testing of the water has turned up unsafe levels of E. coli bacteria caused by fecal matter, but tests earlier this month showed acceptable bacteria levels. In an effort to silence skeptics, last week Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo followed through on her promise to take a dip in the Seine and declared the waters perfectly safe.\n\nFollowing the previous Summer Games' addition of skateboarding and surfing, another sport with counterculture roots will take the Olympics stage for the first time in Paris. Breaking -- best known to the uninitiated as \"break-dancing\" -- is a dance style said to have originated in the 1970s from the streets of New York City's South Bronx and inspired by the break beats and hip-hop tracks played by DJs and MCs. But the athleticism involved in the art form -- head-spins, backflips and other acrobatics -- is undeniable.\n\nBreaking became more mainstream in the 1990s as it entered pop culture and expanded in popularity through international competition. And in 2016, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) added breaking to the 2018 Youth Olympic Games in Buenos Aires.\n\nAlthough it's an American export, other countries including Japan, Canada and The Netherlands boast talent that's been known to surpass the U.S. competitively.\n\nIn Paris, 16 b-boys (male breakers) and 16 b-girls will go head to head in separate battles at Place de la Concorde, an outdoor public square. The women's competition is set for Aug. 9 and men's is on Aug. 10. On Team USA, look out for medal contenders Victor Montalvo and Grace \"Sunny\" Choi.\n\nThe same U.S. women's gymnastics team that took home a silver medal at the Tokyo Games all-around final in 2021 is hoping to rewrite their Olympic ending in Paris.\n\nThree years ago, Biles, who at 27 is the most decorated gymnast of all time, came down with a case of the \"twisties,\" a debilitating psychological affliction that forced her to pull out of several events to focus on her mental health. In her place, Suni Lee had emerged as the unlikely champion, and went on to earn a gold medal in the individual all-around competition in Tokyo.\n\nJoining Biles and Lee are Jordan Chiles, Jade Carey, and 16-year-old newcomer Hezly Rivera.\n\nNow, with Biles in top form and the team united in its goal of \"redemption,\" the women's squad is the favorite to win gold. And especially so, given that Russia, the defending gold medalist, won't be there. The IOC plans to allow only some Russian athletes to compete as \"individual neutral athletes\" under strict conditions it set in response to Russia's war in Ukraine. The country's absence also improves the men's chances of medaling in a sport normally dominated by Russia, China and Japan.\n\nEntering her fourth Olympics, Katie Ledecky continues to dominate the 800- and 1,500-meter freestyle events, in both of which she still holds the world records. Seven of her Olympic medals are gold, putting her just two wins away from earning the most Olympic gold medals of any female athlete in history. Younger swimmers have Ledecky beat in the 400-meter freestyle: Australia's Ariarne Titmus (who took gold in Tokyo and also reigns in the 200-meter event) and Canada's Summer McIntosh have each knocked down Ledecky's world record, which Titmus currently holds. The Titmus-McIntosh-Ledecky 400-meter race should make for a thrilling watch.\n\nIn men's swimming, the U.S. is looking for a superstar and hoping that Caeleb Dressel is it. The 27-year-old won five gold medals in Tokyo -- joining an elite few of swimmers that have won that many in a single Games, including Michael Phelps and Mark Spitz. After taking an eight-month break from the sport, Dressel showed at the Olympic trials last month that he's still fast in sprints.\n\nHeading into Paris, however, the two fastest swimmers in the world are not from the usual rival powerhouses (Australia and the U.S.) but from Canada -- McIntosh on the women's -- and France -- L\u00e9on Marchand.\n\nA doping scandal sparked international outrage after it was revealed in April that 32 Chinese swimmers tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug ahead of the Tokyo Games in 2021 but were cleared to compete. The drug in question -- called trimetazidine or TMZ -- is the same one found in a sample from Kamila Valieva, the Russian figure skater who was subsequently slapped with a four-year ban from international competition.\n\nChinese officials say an unintentional contamination led to the positive tests. The World Anti-Doping Agency accepted that explanation after its investigation and said that international doping rules don't require them to ban the athletes.\n\nThe U.S. Justice Department has opened a criminal probe into the case involving the swimmers. Meanwhile, China is expected to send 11 of the 32 swimmers who had the performance drug in their system in 2021 to compete in Paris.\n\nThe agency's handling of the positive tests has sowed doubt deeper among critics who question whether the regulatory body responsible for curbing cheating holds some countries to a lower standard than others.\n\nThe 100-meter sprint, the most popular track event, has shaped up to be a familiar two-nation race. Representing Jamaica in the women's race is Shericka Jackson, whose biggest challenge is American Sha'Carri Richardson. But don't overlook Jamaican sprint queen Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, who will race in her fifth and final Olympics 16 years after becoming the first Caribbean woman to win the 100-meter gold. They are chasing Florence Griffith Joyner's record set in 1988.\n\nIn the 200-meter, there's a real chance we could see the fall of Flo-Jo's world record set that same year when she ran 21.34 seconds. Jackson will go head-to-head with teammate Elaine Thompson-Herah and Gabby Thomas of Team USA.\n\nIn the men's 100-meter race, Noah Lyles on Team USA will face Jamaica's Oblique Seville and Kishane Thompson, each aiming to break the world record time set by eight-time Olympic gold medalist Usain Bolt. Still, the field is brimming with talent that clouds podium predictions. Other top contenders include reigning Olympic champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and a former world champion American Fred Kerley.\n\nLyles also racing in the 200-meter -- his better event -- a race that won't be as wide open as the 100. He's the favorite, ahead of Tebogo, a notable exception to the rivalry who won the men's race last week at an international meet in Monaco.\n\nSoccer starts before the Games officially kick off with the opening ceremony. The U.S. women's national team is aiming to upgrade their bronze medal from Tokyo. The four-time gold medalists haven't taken first on the podium since the 2012 Games in London. Since the retirement of major stars -- Megan Rapinoe, Carli Lloyd, Julie Ertz, Sam Mewis -- has made way for a younger team, which will be led by new head coach Emma Hayes, former manager of the women's Chelsea Football Club. World Cup champion Spain is the favorite to take gold.\n\nThe last time the U.S. sent a men's soccer team to the Olympics was in 2008, and they haven't medaled since 1904. Since the rule to restrict the competition to players under 23 went into effect in 1992, the men's team has advanced to the knockout stage only once.\n\nThe men kick off their tournament on Wednesday in a game against host country France, a favorite to win it all. The women's squad plays Zambia on Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "wfae.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "WFAE 90.7 - Charlotte's NPR News Source"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/football-chaos-paris-olympics-kicks-off-1849902", "title": "Football Chaos As Paris Olympics Kicks Off", "body": "The sporting programme at the Paris Olympics endured a chaotic start on Wednesday as men's football kicked off and a huge police operation was put in place for Israel's first appearance at the Games.\n\nTwo days before the opening ceremony, Morocco beat Argentina 2-1 in Saint-Etienne, but only after a late equaliser for the South American side was disallowed and the final minutes were played out in an empty stadium following crowd trouble.\n\nArgentina thought they had escaped with a 2-2 draw when Cristian Medina scored in the 16th minute of added time.\n\nBut as their players celebrated, projectiles including bottles and plastic cups rained down from the stands and several spectators entered the pitch, with the referee promptly blowing the whistle.\n\nThe teams left the playing area, but the referee had not blown for full-time and the outcome of the match was unclear until the sides finally reappeared two hours later to play out three more minutes in a stadium that was by now emptied of spectators.\n\nMedina's goal was eventually disallowed for offside following a review and Morocco celebrated a 2-1 win.\n\nIsrael's footballers later Wednesday take on Mali under the watchful eye of 1,000 police officers, with authorities erecting an \"anti-terrorist perimeter\" and bracing for possible disruption around the stadium.\n\nIsrael's participation in Paris has been a key talking point in the run-up, with calls from the Palestine Olympic Committee and some left-wing French MPs for the country to be excluded over the Gaza war.\n\nA packed Stade de France cheered on Antoine Dupont -- arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games -- but he was unable to lead the hosts to victory in a 12-12 draw with the United States.\n\n\"It's always a lot of emotion when you play with all your supporters so it's important to deal with that and to be better even with the pressure,\" admitted the 27-year-old.\n\nAustralia laid down a marker to France and double champions Fiji with a 21-14 win over Samoa at a packed Stade de France.\n\nAs the clock ticks down towards Friday's opening ceremony along the Seine, Olympic chiefs awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps and the 2034 event to Salt Lake City.\n\nBut in a dramatic twist they warned the US city could be stripped of the Games if American authorities kept up their feud with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA).\n\nJohn Coates, the chairman of the IOC's legal commission, said the host city contract confirming Salt Lake's right to stage the Olympics had been altered to allow the IOC to strip it of the Games if US authorities did not respect the \"supreme authority\" of WADA.\n\nThe US anti-doping agency (USADA) has been a vocal critic of WADA for much of the past decade and tensions escalated this year after reports in April revealed that 23 Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance ahead of the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, but were subsequently cleared to compete at the Games.\n\nUSADA chief Travis Tygart accused Olympic bosses of \"stooping to threats\".\n\n\"Today's demonstration further showed that as it stands today, WADA is just a sport lapdog, and clean athletes have little chance,\" said Tygart.\n\nThe Olympics lost a top star when tennis world number one Jannik Sinner withdrew with tonsillitis with the Italian admitting he was \"sad and disappointed\".\n\nPreparations for Friday's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athletes' parade along the River Seine.\n\nAround 6,000-7,000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre (four-mile) stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500,000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments.\n\nThe area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced.\n\nBut videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers.\n\nAmerican rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame this Friday as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse by one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, who has been suspended.\n\nThe film showed the three-time Olympic champion walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while apparently training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris.\n\nIn a further scandal, an assistant coach and an analyst with the Canadian women's football team were sent home for their part in spying on rivals.\n\nThe analyst, 43-year-old Joey Lombardi, was also given a suspended eight-month prison sentence for flying a drone over a New Zealand training session.\n\nLombardi pleaded guilty when he appeared in court in Saint-Etienne on Wednesday, the court told AFP.\n\nThe assistant coach was Jasmine Mander, to whom Lombardi reported.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times AU"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", In May, the IOC announced the largest-ever Refugee Olympic Team for Paris 2024, consisting of 36 athletes.\n\nThe Refugee Olympic Team will compete for the third time, having first been introduced at Rio 2016 with 10 athletes. The Tokyo 2020 team included 29 displaced athletes.\n\nThe 36 athletes from 11 different countries of origin will compete in 12 sporting disciplines at Paris 2024, including swimming, athletics, boxing, road cycling, judo, taekwondo, weightlifting and wrestling.\n\nBillions are expected to watch Paris 2024 on TV, and millions of spectators will attend events at 35 venues.\n\nThere will be 754 sessions (competitions and ceremonies) during the Games in the French capital.\n\nAdditionally, 45,000 volunteers and 20,000 accredited journalists will work during the Paris Games.\n\nThe Paris Games will be held at 35 venues, including Stade de France, Parc des Princes and Stade Roland-Garros, across the country.\n\nThe athletes will compete not only in Paris but also at sports venues around France and its territories.\n\nVenues outside Paris include Bordeaux Stadium, Geoffroy-Guichard Stadium in Saint-Etienne, La Beaujoire Stadium in Nantes, Lyon Stadium, Marseille Stadium, Nice Stadium, and Pierre-Mauroy Stadium in Lille.\n\nSeparately, Tahiti's Teahupo'o will host the summer Games' surfing competitions as athletes vie for medals in the Pacific Ocean waves.\n\nTahiti is the largest island in French Polynesia.\n\nThe Paris 2024 Olympic medals feature a hexagonal piece of iron from the Eiffel Tower at the center of a large round radiant medal.\n\nThe reverse side of the 2024 medal depicts the ancient Greek goddess of victory, Nike.\n\nAdditionally, Nike is portrayed emerging from Athens' Panathenaic Stadium, which was an Olympic venue in 2004 and hosted the first modern Games {"uri": "8241229455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:23:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:23:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:22:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/24/07/2024/let-the-games-begin-rugby-football-kick-off-paris-2024", "title": "Let the Games begin! Rugby, football kick off Paris 2024", "body": "Paris: Football and Rugby Sevens kick off the sporting action at the Paris Olympics on Wednesday featuring a top French star and a huge police presence.\n\nAs the clock ticks down towards Friday's opening ceremony, Olympic chiefs awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps and the 2034 event to Salt Lake City.\n\nBut in a dramatic twist they warned the US city could be stripped of the Games if American authorities kept up their feud with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA).\n\nAs the sport gets under way two days before the opening ceremony, a packed Stade de France will cheer on Antoine Dupont -- arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games -- as the Rugby Sevens tournament starts.\n\nThe electric Dupont is the biggest draw for the 555,000 fans expected over the six days of rugby action, but France will have their work cut out to stop double Olympic champions Fiji.\n\nFrance and Fiji are in the same pool and will play the United States and Uruguay, before the pair face each other in a mouthwatering clash on Thursday.\n\nOthers to watch in the wide-open competition are traditional rugby powers New Zealand, Australia, Argentina, and Ireland.\n\nIOC warns Salt Lake\n\nThe success of Salt Lake City's bid to host the 2034 Olympics was a foregone conclusion given the Utah city, which hosted the Games in 2002, was the only candidate.\n\nBut the International Olympic Committee said the Games could be revoked if US lawmakers and the United States Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) were not brought into line.\n\nJohn Coates, the chairman of the IOC's legal commission, said the host city contract confirming Salt Lake's right to stage the Olympics had been altered to allow the IOC to strip it of the Games if US authorities did not respect the \"supreme authority\" of WADA.\n\nUSADA has been a vocal critic of WADA for much of the past decade and tensions escalated this year after reports in April revealed that 23 Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance ahead of the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, but were subsequently cleared to compete at the Games.\n\nThe IOC handed the 2030 games to France but under the condition that Paris stumps up the required financial commitments.\n\nSecurity lockdown\n\nPreparations for Friday's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athletes' parade along the River Seine.\n\nAround 6,000-7,000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre (four-mile) stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500,000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments.\n\nThe area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced.\n\nBut videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers.\n\nAmerican rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame this Friday as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse by one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, who has been suspended.\n\nThe film showed the three-time Olympic champion walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while apparently training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris.", "source": {"uri": "thepeninsulaqatar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Peninsula"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242557928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:23:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:23:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:23:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/big-goals-gambles-paris-aims-reset-olympics-audacious-112259149", "title": "With big goals and gambles, Paris aims to reset the Olympics with audacious Games and a wow opening", "body": "PARIS -- Paris has long been a city of dreamers: Just look at the Eiffel Tower, for decades the world's loftiest structure. Audacity also underpins the French capital's plans for its first Olympic Games in a century, which open Friday with an opening ceremony for the ages.\n\nThe most sprawling and elaborate Olympic opening ever -- a gala spectacular Friday evening on the River Seine that even French President Emmanuel Macron says initially felt like \"a crazy and not very serious idea\" -- kicks off 16 days of competition that promise to be ground-breaking, with nearly every corner of the city hosting some aspect of competition.\n\nAfter two toned-down, pandemic-hampered Olympics, expect a bold celebration. The heady marriage of sports and France's world-renowned capital of fashion, gastronomy and culture could also help secure the Olympics' longer-term future.\n\nOlympic organizers were struggling to find suitable host cities for their flagship Summer Games when they settled on Paris in 2017, enticed by its promise of innovations and the potential for the city of romance to rekindle love for the Olympics, especially with younger audiences that have so many other entertainment options.\n\nBut Paris' challenges are huge, too.\n\nThe city that has been repeatedly struck by deadly extremist attacks has to safeguard 10,500 athletes and millions of visitors. The international context of wars in Ukraine and Gaza add layers of complication for the gargantuan security effort. French elite special forces are part of the security detail for Israel's delegation.\n\nStill, if all goes well, Paris hopes to be remembered as a before-and-after Olympic watershed.\n\nThe first Games with nearly equal numbers of men and women, an advance that's been a long time coming since 22 women first got accepted as Olympians 124 years ago, also in Paris, will take another step toward aligning the Olympics with the post-#MeToo world.\n\nParis also hopes to reassure climate-conscious Generations Z and beyond by staging Games that are less polluting, more sustainable and more socially virtuous than their predecessors. Many of the sports venues are temporary, because Paris didn't want to repeat the mistake of previous Olympic host cities that built new arenas and then had no use for them.\n\nWith iconic Paris monuments as backdrops -- beach volleyball in the Eiffel Tower's shadow -- and breakdancing added to a growing list of Olympic sports that target young audiences, expect plenty of viral moments on Instagram, TikTok and elsewhere.\n\nCrowds will be back for the first time since the coronavirus pandemic forced Tokyo to push back its Games to 2021 and keep spectators away, and the Beijing Winter Games in 2022, when China was locked down.\n\nPrize-winning French theater director Thomas Jolly is turning central Paris into an open-air stage for the opening ceremony that will run through sunset and showcase France, its people and their history. The 330-meter-tall (1,083-foot-tall) Eiffel Tower will surely feature prominently.\n\nHundreds of thousands of people, including 320,000 paying and invited ticket-holders, are expected to line the Seine's banks as athletes are paraded along the river on boats.\n\nDuring the extravaganza, a no-fly zone extending for 150 kilometers (93 miles) around the capital will close Paris' skies, policed by fighter jets, airspace-monitoring AWACS surveillance flights, surveillance drones, helicopters that can carry sharpshooters and drone-disabling equipment.\n\nShowcasing and celebrating Paris could be joyously cathartic for the city that was plunged into mourning by extremist attacks in 2015.\n\nGuesses about the identity of the person or people who might get the honor of lighting the Olympic cauldron include soccer icon Zinedine Zidane and other French sporting heroes, but also survivors of Islamic State-group gunmen and suicide bombers who killed 130 people on Nov. 13, 2015.\n\nParis is also taking gambles in hopes of leaving an indelible impression on the Olympics' global audience of billions.\n\nThe decision not to stage the opening ceremony in the traditional setting of France's biggest stadium -- the Stade de France that was among the 2015 attackers' targets and is now the venue for Olympic track and field and rugby sevens -- and to host skateboarding, archery and other sports in temporary arenas in the heart of Paris have made safeguarding the Games more complex.\n\nRights campaigners and Games critics worry about the broad scope and scale of Olympic security, including the use of AI-equipped surveillance technology.\n\nThe furthest venue is on the other side of the world in the French Pacific territory of Tahiti, where Olympic surfers will compete on famously giant waves that first form in storm belts off Antarctica.\n\nUp to 45,000 police and gendarmes, plus 10,000 soldiers, are safeguarding Paris and its suburbs that together are hosting most of the 32 sports that will crown Olympic champions in 329 medal events. The gold, silver and bronze medals they'll hand out are inlaid with a hexagonal, polished chunk of iron taken from the Eiffel Tower.\n\nThe Seine's banks and riverside roads and more than a dozen of its bridges were fenced off nine days ahead of the opening ceremony, creating a no-go zone for people who haven't applied in advance for passes and making it tough for Parisians and visitors to get around and see the sights in the city of 2 million. Owners of restaurants and other businesses inside the security fence are howling about fewer customers.\n\nLimiting new construction has saved money and, Paris organizers say, contributed to their goal of halving the Games' overall carbon footprint compared with London in 2012 and Rio in 2016. Among the new venues, an Olympic aquatics center in Seine Saint-Denis is expected to help that underprivileged suburb of northern Paris teach more children to swim.\n\nFrench organizers argue that the Games will leave positive impacts on Paris long after the Olympians and Paralympic athletes who follow from Aug. 28 to Sept. 8 have departed.\n\nA costly and complex cleanup of the long-polluted Seine, sped up by the deadline of the Games, is expected to reopen the river to public swimming next year, after Olympic marathon swimmers and triathletes have competed in it. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip this month to demonstrate that its waters are safe.\n\nWith estimated overall costs of around 9 billion euros ($9.7 billion), more than half from sponsors, ticket sales and other non-public funding, Paris' expenses so far are less than for Tokyo, Rio and London.\n\nOnce opening ceremony fireworks have become memories, the City of Light will then become the playground of Olympians.\n\nAmerican gymnastics superstar Simon Biles is back. French-born basketball phenom Victor Wembanyama will carry home hopes on his 7-foot-4 (2.24-meter) frame. Ukrainian and Palestinian athletes have points they want to prove about conflict, resilience and sacrifice that go beyond the realms of sport.\n\nThe lucky few will win medals. Many will wish they had gone higher, faster and stronger.", "source": {"uri": "abcnews.go.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243007657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:07:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:07:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:04:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13671867/EXPLAINER-Olympics-What-need-know-Paris-2024-opening-ceremony.html", "title": "EXPLAINER-Olympics-What you need to know about the Paris 2024...", "body": "By Ingrid Melander\n\nPARIS, July 25 (Reuters) - Paris will officially kick off its Olympics extravaganza with an unprecedented opening ceremony on the river Seine on Friday.\n\nHere is what you need to know about the ceremony:\n\nWHEN AND WHERE IS THE OPENING CEREMONY TAKING PLACE?\n\nFor the first time, the Games' opening ceremony will not take place in a stadium.\n\nInstead, around 85 boats will carry nearly 7,000 athletes on a 6km floating parade on the Seine, at the heart of Paris.\n\nDeparting from the Austerlitz bridge, they will sail past the Notre-Dame cathedral and arrive near the Eiffel Tower, after passing under bridges and gateways, including the Pont des Arts and Pont Neuf, and near many of the French capital's landmarks.\n\nThe ceremony is due to start at 7.30 p.m. (1730 GMT) and last about three hours and 45 minutes.\n\nWHAT WILL WE SEE?\n\nOrganisers have promised a show like no other.\n\nThey say it will be daring and joyful and take advantage of the historic monuments, riverbanks, sky and water \"and there won't be a single riverbank or bridge that won't be filled with music, dance, or performance.\"\n\nSome 80 giant screens along the way will broadcast the show, which will include a floating parade of athletes and artists and is also expected to feature dancers performing from the roof of buildings along the Seine.\n\nThe show will be \"a large fresco\" celebrating Paris, France and the Games and will interweave the parade of athletes, artistic performances and elements of protocol, said Thomas Jolly, the artistic director of the opening ceremony.\n\nDetails including who will light the Olympic cauldron to mark the start of the Games, or which artists are taking part, have been kept secret.\n\nBut Lady Gaga and Celine Dion are among singers who have been spotted in Paris, triggering rumors they could take part in the ceremony.\n\nFrench media said Franco-Malian pop star Aya Nakamura, the most listened to French female singer in the world, will sing a song by the late Charles Aznavour.\n\nNakamura was the target of racist abuse online when it was first rumored that she would take part in the ceremony. She sings in French, with frequent use of slang, her style influenced by West Indies zouk music, mixing in American R'n'B and Afrobeats.\n\nOne big unknown is the weather. It is currently forecast to be cloudy, when organizers were hoping there would be a \"golden hour\" of sunset lighting up buildings midway through the ceremony.\n\nWHO WILL BE THERE?\n\nThe show will be attended by over 80 heads of state and government and more than 300,000 spectators will watch from the river's banks, organizers said.\n\nThe Paris 2024 committee said some 222,000 people would get free invites, while 104,000 will have to buy a ticket.\n\nBoats carrying the athletes will be equipped with cameras to allow those watching on TV or their phone to get a close-up view, the committee said.\n\nWHAT ABOUT SECURITY?\n\nOrganizing the ceremony in the heart of an iconic city like Paris may make for great pictures, but it's also a major security challenge.\n\nSome 2,000 private security staff and 45,000 police will be dispatched to ensure the ceremony's security, including special intervention forces. Snipers will be deployed on the top of buildings along the route. An anti-drone system will be in place.\n\nSpectators and local residents need to carry permits on a QR code to get anywhere near the riverbanks. Cars won't be allowed into the area, with few exceptions.\n\nNearby metro stations will be closed, as will many of the bridges. No planes will be allowed to fly over Paris - unless they are part of the ceremony.\n\nWith wars in Gaza and Ukraine, and security concerns at home, France already has its security alert at its highest level.\n\nOfficials have said there are no specific terror threats to the ceremony.\n\nThe main potential risk would be from a lone attacker, officials have said over the past months, while also flagging potential petty crime and possible protests, from environmental activists, the far right and far left, the pro-Palestinian movement or others.\n\nA man was arrested in May in Saint-Etienne, suspected of planning an attack in the name of Islamic State at the city's soccer stadium during the Olympics.\n\nA right-wing sympathizer was arrested in eastern France in July on suspicion of plotting attacks to take place during the Olympics.\n\nPAST SUMMER OLYMPICS' OPENING CEREMONIES\n\nTokyo 2020: The opening ceremony was overshadowed by the COVID-19 pandemic. Postponed by a year due to the coronavirus, the Games were held largely without spectators.\n\nRio 2016: Financially constrained Brazil had little choice but to put on a more low-key show, with minimal technology and a heavy dependence on the country's Carnival party traditions.\n\nLondon 2012: The 86-year-old Queen Elizabeth put aside royal reserve in a video where she stepped onto a helicopter with James Bond actor Daniel Craig to be carried aloft from Buckingham Palace as part of a dizzying ceremony designed to highlight the grandeur and eccentricities of the nation.\n\nBeijing 2008: About one billion people, or 15% of the world's population, watched the opening ceremony, which involved 10,000 performers, 2008 drummers and a dramatic sky-walking finale. {"uri": "2024-07-432948374", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:36:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:36:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:06:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/how-to-watch-the-2024-olympics-opening-ceremony/article_cd1c3934-458a-56f9-b55f-b85e314831fe.html", "title": "How to watch the 2024 Olympics opening ceremony", "body": "The opening ceremony for the Paris Olympics is set for Friday.\n\nInstead of a traditional march into a stadium, about 10,500 athletes will parade on more than 90 boats on the Seine River for 6 kilometers (3.7 miles). This will start the ceremony, not mark the end of it, another break from tradition.\n\nWhat time does the opening ceremony start?\n\nThe ceremony starts at 1:30 p.m. EDT/7:30 p.m. CEST and is expected to last more than three hours.\n\nWhere is the opening ceremony be\n\ning held?\n\nThe parade starts at the Austerlitz Bridge beside the Jardin des Plantes and follows the course of the Seine from east to west. It makes its way around two islands in the center of the city before passing under several bridges and gateways. Athletes aboard the boats will get glimpses of several Olympic venues including La Concorde Urban Park (3X3 basketball, breaking, BMX freestyle cycling, skateboarding), Invalides (archery, athletics -- marathon finish, road cycling -- time trial start) and the Grand Palais (fencing, taekwondo). The parade ends at the Iena Bridge, which links the Eiffel Tower on the left bank of the Seine to the Trocad\u00e9ro district on the right bank. The ceremony's finale is at the Trocad\u00e9ro. There, among other ceremonial procedures, French President Emmanuel Macron will deliver opening remarks.\n\nHow can I watch t\n\nhe opening ceremony?\n\nThe ceremony will air on NBC and stream on Peacock and NBC Olympic platforms -- NBCOlympics.com, NBC.com, NBC app, NBC Olympics app.\n\nA preview will air on NBC at noon EDT, with live coverage beginning at 1:30 p.m. and an enhanced prime-time encore at 7:30 p.m.\n\nAbout 220,000 invited and security-screened spectators are expected to fill the upper tiers of the Seine's banks, and an additional 104,000 paying spectators will watch from the lower riverside and around the Trocad\u00e9ro plaza.\n\nThose in Paris who could not get tickets will be able to watch the ceremony on 80 giant screens set up throughout the city.\n\nWho is performing at the opening ceremony?\n\nIn addition to the athletes who will participate in the parade, 3,000 dancers, artists and other athletes will be featured in the opening and closing ceremonies. Most of the entertainment acts remain under wraps. The reason why these two languages are spoken has now been revealed ahead of the Paris 2024 Games. The Paris Olympics gets underway on the 26th of July, culminating on the 11th of August.\n\nWith the Paris Olympics just days away, over 10,000 athletes will be getting ready to put to work years of training and preparation in a bid to win gold for their respective sport and respective country. As with every Olympic event, anticipation is rife, especially with the last summer Games having been in Tokyo 2021, the first ever odd-numbered Olympic event, due to the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nParis 2024 will mark a return to Olympic normality, with the United States of America hoping they can defend their record of having won every summer Games since 1996, a record that sees them hold the record for most medals won in Olympic history, with 2,968 medals.\n\nAs much as the Olympic Games is about sports, and discovering a new-found love for sports and athletes you've never seen, as well as supporting the sports and athletes you love, there is one aspect of the Games that millions of people tune in for every four years, and that is the opening ceremony.\n\nOlympics Opening Ceremony\n\nParis has decided to make history with their version of the opening ceremony, with it set to take place on the river Seine, marking it as the first time an Olympics opening ceremony has taken place outside, and not inside a stadium. Despite it being exactly a century since France has hosted the summer Games, people will have noticed that in the events that have taken place since, that French is always spoken, and there is a fascinating reason why.\n\nWhy French is spoken at every opening ceremony\n\nEver since 1896, the Olympic Games has been synonymous with the French language, and that is because it is the official language of the Games, alongside English. Having been dormant since the Ancient Greek era of athletic showcasing, 1896 marked the revival of the Olympic Games, with Frenchman, Pierre de Coubertin, seen to be the father of the modern Games.\n\nDue to his involvement, France has always been synonymous with the Games, with the French language being seen as the language of diplomacy, and lots of people dedicate that to Coubertin, with many believing his work on the Games being a key reason as to why France was made the first official language of the Olympic Games.\n\nIt is due to this that with every Olympic opening ceremony, announcements are made in both French and English, due to their roles as official languages. Announcements would also be made in the native tongue of the host city, but due to this year's Olympics emanating from France, there will be no need, as French is already involved. This same rule of thumb applies to the closing ceremonies, meaning that the Paris 2024 Olympic Games will only have French and English involved.\n\nRelated Why Team GB Athlete Charlotte Dujardin Withdrew From Olympics\n\nA video has surfaced showing Charlotte Dujardin whipping a horse during a coaching session, leading to her withdrawing from the Olympics.\n\nA fascinating reason, and a homage to the history of the Games, Paris 2024 will mark the third time that France has hosted, with many athletes having just arrived at the Olympic Village ahead of this weekend's opening ceremony.\n\nThe two-week-long event will start on the 26th of July, and culminate on the 11th of August, as the USA will hope to win an eighth successive summer Games ahead of them hosting it in This will start the ceremony, not mark the end of it, another break from tradition.\n\nWhat time does the opening ceremony start?\n\nThe ceremony starts at 1:30 a.m. Philippine time on July 27 (1:30 pm EDT/7:30 p.m. CEST July 26) and is expected to last more than three hours.\n\nWhere is the opening ceremony being held?\n\nThe parade starts at the Austerlitz Bridge beside the Jardin des Plantes and follows the course of the Seine from east to west. It makes its way around two islands in the center of the city before passing under several bridges and gateways.\n\nAthletes aboard the boats will get glimpses of several Paris Olympics venues including La Concorde Urban Park (3X3 basketball, breaking, BMX freestyle cycling, skateboarding), Invalides (archery, athletics -- marathon finish, road cycling -- time trial start) and the Grand Palais (fencing, taekwondo). The parade ends at the Iena Bridge, which links the Eiffel Tower on the left bank of the Seine to the Trocad\u00e9ro district on the right bank.\n\nThe ceremony's finale is at the Trocad\u00e9ro. There, among other ceremonial procedures, French President Emmanuel Macron will deliver opening remarks.\n\nHow and where can I watch theopening ceremony?\n\nIn the Philippines, official broadcasters Cignal TV/One Sports Digital will carry the opening ceremony that will feature Team Philippines in the Parade of Nations. Tokyo Olympics silver medalists Nesthy Petecio and Carlo Paalam will serve as the flag bearers for the Philippines.\n\nAccording to One Sports, the opening festivities will be aired on its Facebook & YouTube accounts, free-to-air channel One Sports, One Sports+ and Cignal TV Pop-up channels 1 & 2 on cable TV, and Pilipinas Live via streaming. It will be featured on the 2:30pm telecast on RPTV.\n\nREAD: Team Philippines in Paris Olympics 2024: Meet the athletes\n\nAbout 220,000 invited and security-screened spectators are expected to fill the upper tiers of the Seine's banks, and an additional 104,000 paying spectators will watch from the lower riverside and around the Trocad\u00e9ro plaza.\n\nThose in Paris who could not get tickets will be able to watch the ceremony on 80 giant screens set up throughout the city.\n\nWho is performing at the opening ceremony?\n\nIn addition to the athletes who will participate in the parade, 3,000 dancers, artists and other athletes will be featured in the opening and closing ceremonies. Most of the entertainment acts remain under wraps.\n\nNBC News reported that Celine Dion and Lady Gaga have arrived in Paris amid speculation that one or both of the pop singers will perform at the {"uri": "8242636319", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "08:16:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T08:16:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T08:15:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/sports/paris-2024-olympic-games-opening-ceremony-to-be-held-friday/3284979", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympic Games' opening ceremony to be held Friday", "body": "French capital to host Summer Olympics from July 26 to Aug. 11 as 10,500 athletes to compete for medals\n\nThe Paris 2024 Olympic Games will officially start with an exceptional opening ceremony across the River Seine on Friday evening.\n\nIt will be the first time that an opening ceremony of the Olympics will not be held at a stadium.\n\n\"Paris 2024 is breaking new ground by bringing sports into the city and the same will be true of the Opening Ceremony, set to be held in the heart of the city along its main artery: the Seine,\" the Paris 2024 statement read.\n\n\"The river parade will follow the course of the Seine, from east to west over 6 kilometers (3.7 miles),\" it said and adding that nearly 100 boats will carry 10,500 athletes, who will go for medals at Paris 2024.\n\nIt will be open to the general public.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron is expected to open the games.\n\nThe athletes, who will represent 206 National Olympic Committees (NOCs), and nearly 120 heads of state, sovereigns and heads of government will attend the games.\n\nA number of 329 events will be held during the 2024 Summer Olympics from July 26 to Aug. 11.\n\nDuring the 19 days of competition, handball, football and rugby matches took place from July 24, a couple of days before the opening ceremony.\n\nAt Paris 2024, there are 32 sports disciplines including four additional sports; surfing, climbing, skateboarding, and breaking, which is a dancesport discipline.\n\nIn addition to the countries, there is a IOC (International Olympic Committee) Refugee Olympic Team. In May, the IOC named the largest-ever IOC Refugee Olympic Team Paris 2024, which has 36 athletes.\n\nThe Refugee Olympic Team will compete in the Olympics for a third time, as it was introduced at Rio 2016. It consisted of 10 athletes for the Summer Games in Brazil. There were 29 displaced athletes, who made the Tokyo 2020 team previously.\n\nThe 36 athletes from 11 different countries of origin will compete in 12 sporting disciplines at Paris 2024 such as swimming, athletics, boxing, road cycling, judo, taekwondo, weightlifting, and wrestling.\n\nBillions will watch the Paris 2024 on TV, and millions of spectators will do the same at 35 venues.\n\nThere are 754 sessions (competitions and ceremonies) during the sporting events in the French capital.\n\nIn addition 45,000 volunteers, and 20,000 accredited journalists will work during the Paris games.\n\nThe Paris Games will be held at 35 venues including Stade de France, Parc des Princes and Stade Roland-Garros throughout the country.\n\nThe athletes will not only compete in Paris, but also at the sports venues around France and its territories.\n\nBordeaux Stadium, Geoffroy-Guichard Stadium in Saint-Etienne, La Beaujoire Stadium in Nantes, Lyon Stadium, Marseille Stadium, Nice Stadium, Pierre Mauroy Stadium in Lille are among the 35 venues but they are all outside Paris.\n\nSeparately Tahiti's Teahupo'o will host the summer games' surfing competitions as the athletes will vie for medals in the waves of the Pacific Ocean.\n\nTahiti is the largest island of French Polynesia.\n\nEiffel Tower's metal chunks at center of Paris 2024 medals\n\nThe Paris 2024 Olympic medals feature an hexagonal piece of iron from the city's famous Eiffel Tower, and it is placed at the center of a large round radiant medal.\n\nThe other side of the 2024 medal shows the ancient Greek goddess of victory Nike.\n\nIn addition, Nike emerges from Athens' Panathenaic Stadium, which was an 2004 Olympic venue and the home to the first modern Games in 1896.\n\nAt the Paris There, among other ceremonial procedures, French President Emmanuel Macron will deliver opening remarks.\n\nPolice officers are pictured on the river Seine during the tour. | Photo Credit: Reuters\n\nThe ceremony will air on NBC and stream on Peacock and NBC Olympic platforms -- NBCOlympics.com, NBC.com, NBC app, NBC Olympics app.\n\nA preview will air on NBC at noon EDT, with live coverage beginning at 1:30 p.m. and an enhanced prime-time encore at 7:30 p.m.\n\nAbout 220,000 invited and security-screened spectators are expected to fill the upper tiers of the Seine's banks, and an additional 104,000 paying spectators will watch from the lower riverside and around the Trocad\u00e9ro plaza.\n\nThose in Paris who could not get tickets will be able to watch the ceremony on 80 giant screens set up throughout the city.\n\nIn addition to the athletes who will participate in the parade, 3,000 dancers, artists and other athletes will be featured in the opening and closing ceremonies. {"uri": "8242558248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:24:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:24:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:23:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/paris-ap-eiffel-tower-french-emmanuel-macron-b2585604.html", "title": "With big goals and gambles, Paris aims to reset the Olympics with audacious Games and a wow opening", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nParis has long been a city of dreamers: Just look at the Eiffel Tower, for decades the world's loftiest structure. Audacity also underpins the French capital's plans for its first Olympic Games in a century, which open Friday with an opening ceremony for the ages.\n\nThe most sprawling and elaborate Olympic opening ever -- a gala spectacular Friday evening on the River Seine that even French President Emmanuel Macron says initially felt like \"a crazy and not very serious idea\" -- kicks off 16 days of competition that promise to be ground-breaking, with nearly every corner of the city hosting some aspect of competition.\n\nAfter two toned-down, pandemic-hampered Olympics, expect a bold celebration. The heady marriage of sports and France's world-renowned capital of fashion, gastronomy and culture could also help secure the Olympics' longer-term future.\n\nOlympic organizers were struggling to find suitable host cities for their flagship Summer Games when they settled on Paris in 2017, enticed by its promise of innovations and the potential for the city of romance to rekindle love for the Olympics, especially with younger audiences that have so many other entertainment options.\n\nThe city that has been repeatedly struck by deadly extremist attacks has to safeguard 10,500 athletes and millions of visitors. The international context of wars in Ukraine and Gaza add layers of complication for the gargantuan security effort. French elite special forces are part of the security detail for Israel's delegation.\n\nStill, if all goes well, Paris hopes to be remembered as a before-and-after Olympic watershed.\n\nThe first Games with nearly equal numbers of men and women, an advance that's been a long time coming since 22 women first got accepted as Olympians 124 years ago, also in Paris, will take another step toward aligning the Olympics with the post-#MeToo world.\n\nParis also hopes to reassure climate-conscious Generations Z and beyond by staging Games that are less polluting, more sustainable and more socially virtuous than their predecessors. Many of the sports venues are temporary, because Paris didn't want to repeat the mistake of previous Olympic host cities that built new arenas and then had no use for them.\n\nWith iconic Paris monuments as backdrops -- beach volleyball in the Eiffel Tower's shadow -- and breakdancing added to a growing list of Olympic sports that target young audiences, expect plenty of viral moments on Instagram, TikTok and elsewhere.\n\nCrowds will be back for the first time since the coronavirus pandemic forced Tokyo to push back its Games to 2021 and keep spectators away, and the Beijing Winter Games in 2022, when China was locked down.\n\nPrize-winning French theater director Thomas Jolly is turning central Paris into an open-air stage for the opening ceremony that will run through sunset and showcase France, its people and their history. The 330-meter-tall (1,083-foot-tall) Eiffel Tower will surely feature prominently.\n\nHundreds of thousands of people, including 320,000 paying and invited ticket-holders, are expected to line the Seine's banks as athletes are paraded along the river on boats.\n\nDuring the extravaganza, a no-fly zone extending for 150 kilometers (93 miles) around the capital will close Paris' skies, policed by fighter jets, airspace-monitoring AWACS surveillance flights, surveillance drones, helicopters that can carry sharpshooters and drone-disabling equipment.\n\nHelping Parisians move past the attacks of 2015\n\nShowcasing and celebrating Paris could be joyously cathartic for the city that was plunged into mourning by extremist attacks in 2015.\n\nGuesses about the identity of the person or people who might get the honor of lighting the Olympic cauldron include soccer icon Zinedine Zidane and other French sporting heroes, but also survivors of Islamic State-group gunmen and suicide bombers who killed 130 people on Nov. 13, 2015.\n\nParis is also taking gambles in hopes of leaving an indelible impression on the Olympics' global audience of billions.\n\nThe decision not to stage the opening ceremony in the traditional setting of France's biggest stadium -- the Stade de France that was among the 2015 attackers' targets and is now the venue for Olympic track and field and rugby sevens -- and to host skateboarding, archery and other sports in temporary arenas in the heart of Paris have made safeguarding the Games more complex.\n\nRights campaigners and Games critics worry about the broad scope and scale of Olympic security, including the use of AI-equipped surveillance technology.\n\nParis' reach stretches to the Pacific\n\nThe furthest venue is on the other side of the world in the French Pacific territory of Tahiti, where Olympic surfers will compete on famously giant waves that first form in storm belts off Antarctica.\n\nUp to 45,000 police and gendarmes, plus 10,000 soldiers, are safeguarding Paris and its suburbs that together are hosting most of the 32 sports that will crown Olympic champions in 329 medal events. The gold, silver and bronze medals they'll hand out are inlaid with a hexagonal, polished chunk of iron taken from the Eiffel Tower.\n\nThe Seine's banks and riverside roads and more than a dozen of its bridges were fenced off nine days ahead of the opening ceremony, creating a no-go zone for people who haven't applied in advance for passes and making it tough for Parisians and visitors to get around and see the sights in the city of 2 million. Owners of restaurants and other businesses inside the security fence are howling about fewer customers.\n\nLeaving an Olympic legacy for Paris\n\nLimiting new construction has saved money and, Paris organizers say, contributed to their goal of halving the Games' overall carbon footprint compared with London in 2012 and Rio in 2016. Among the new venues, an Olympic aquatics center in Seine Saint-Denis is expected to help that underprivileged suburb of northern Paris teach more children to swim.\n\nFrench organizers argue that the Games will leave positive impacts on Paris long after the Olympians and Paralympic athletes who follow from Aug. 28 to Sept. 8 have departed.\n\nA costly and complex cleanup of the long-polluted Seine, sped up by the deadline of the Games, is expected to reopen the river to public swimming next year, after Olympic marathon swimmers and triathletes have competed in it. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo took a dip this month to demonstrate that its waters are safe.\n\nWith estimated overall costs of around 9 billion euros ($9.7 billion), more than half from sponsors, ticket sales and other non-public funding, Paris' expenses so far are less than for Tokyo, Rio and London.\n\nOnce opening ceremony fireworks have become memories, the City of Light will then become the playground of Olympians.\n\nAmerican gymnastics superstar Simon Biles is back. French-born basketball phenom Victor Wembanyama will carry home hopes on his 7-foot-4 (2.24-meter) frame. Ukrainian and Palestinian athletes have points they want to prove about conflict, resilience and sacrifice that go beyond the realms of sport.\n\nThe lucky few will win medals. Many will wish they had gone higher, faster and stronger.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8243074417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:48:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:48:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:47:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/sports/whats-new-in-paris-olympics-2024-opening-ceremony-gender-parity-new-sports-13797003.html", "title": "Opening ceremony on river, gender parity: How Paris Olympics 2024 is different from past Summer Games", "body": "Paris is set to host the Summer Olympics for the third time in 2024. Reuters\n\nThe 2024 Paris Olympics will kick off a little over 24 hours from now with the opening ceremony set to take place in River Seine at 11 pm IST (7.30 pm local time).\n\nA few of the events are already underway including football, archery but the Games are not officially considered open until the Opening Ceremony has taken place.\n\nParis Olympics Complete Coverage: Click here for news, schedule, explainers and more\n\nBefore the 33rd Summer Olympics Games get underway, we take a look at what's new in Paris this year:\n\nOpening ceremony outside stadium\n\nParis 2024 is set to standout in Olympic history for having the most unique opening ceremony ever. This year's opening ceremoyn is set to take place at The Seine, the river that flows through the French capital, instead of a stadium as has been a norm over the years.\n\nOver 10,000 athletes will be travelling on around 100 boats during the opening ceremony that will pass through some of Paris' most iconic places including Notre Dame, Pont des Arts and Pont Neuf. The floating parade will begin from the Austerlitz bridge and will end at the Trocad\u00e9ro, where the remainder of the Opening Ceremony will take place.\n\nGender parity\n\nIt was in Paris in 1900 where women athletes competed at the Olympics for the first time. More than a century later, the French capital bears witness to another milestone -- that of a parity between male and female athletes at the world's biggest sporting event.\n\nA total of 10,500 athletes from 206 countries are participating in the 2024 Paris Games, and feature as many man as women. For context, the 1936 Olympics had just 8.4 per cent female participation while the number in the Tokyo 2020 Games was 47.8 per cent.\n\nNew sports\n\nBreaking, more popularly known as breakdancing across the world, will be making its highly-anticipated debut in the Paris Games. What began as a dance form in New York City in the 1970s has slowly evolved into a competitive sport that has its own world championships.\n\nIt was part of the 2018 Youth Olympics in Buenos Aires and is set to experience its biggest moment ever in Paris in July and August. Breaking, however, has not been included for the Los Angeles Olympics four years from now.\n\nAlso canoeing is set to have a new event in Paris 2024 -- kayak cross, where athletes will compete against each other over white-water and through obstacles.\n\nSports such as surfing, climbing and skateboarding are set for a second appearance after they made their debuts in Tokyo 2020.\n\nRepechage rounds in athletics\n\nAthletics, along with swimming, has been at the heart of the modern Olympic Games since the inaugural edition in 1896. After 128 years, the most popular sport at the Summer Olympics is set to have 'repechage' rounds, which is set to change the qualification system for the semi-finals.\n\nRepechage, which is already in place in sports such as wrestling and boxing, will be introduced in all track events from 200m to 1500m, including hurdles events. In the 'repechage' provision, athletes will stand the chance of making the semi-finals even if they don't automatically qualify in round one heats by participating in the repechage heats. It essentially gives a second chance to those who finish outside the top 3 in the heats.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8241039127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:30:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:30:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:29:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.thesouthafrican.com/sport/paris-olympics-2024/let-the-games-begin-rugby-football-kick-off-paris-olympics-2024-schedule-results-medal-winners-breaking/", "title": "Let the Games begin! Rugby, football kick off Paris Olympics 2024", "body": "Israel's footballers take on Mali in the men's competition, under the watchful eye of 1 000 police officers, with authorities erecting an \"anti-terrorist perimeter\" and bracing for possible disruption around the stadium.\n\nA French police source told AFP it was possible that \"people shout insults from the stands\" or that there is \"whistling and flags shown during the hymns, for example.\"\n\nIsrael's participation in Paris has been a key talking point in the run-up, with calls from the Palestinian Olympic Committee and some left-wing French MPs for the country to be excluded over the Gaza war.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stressed the Israeli athletes were \"welcome in our country\", adding it was \"France's responsibility to provide them with security.\"\n\nMeanwhile, a packed Stade de France will cheer on Antoine Dupont - arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games - as the Rugby Sevens tournament starts.\n\nThe electric Dupont is the biggest draw for the 555 000 fans expected over the six days of rugby action, but France will have their work cut out to stop double Olympic champions Fiji.\n\nFrance and Fiji are in the same pool and will play the United States and Uruguay, before the pair face each other in a mouthwatering clash on Thursday.\n\nOthers to watch in the wide-open competition are traditional rugby powers New Zealand, Australia, Argentina, and Ireland.\n\nPreparations for Friday's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athlete's parade along the River Seine.\n\nAround 6 000-7 000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500 000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments.\n\nThe area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced.\n\nBut videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers.\n\nAmerican rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame this Friday as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\nSome Paris business owners grumbled the security measures were hurting their bottom line.\n\n\"We were told there would be loads of people during the Olympics and even before. But in fact, no. There's no one,\" Jonas Seignovert, manager of the Eugene restaurant, told AFP.\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse that led to one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, being ejected from the Paris Games.\n\nThe video showed three-time Olympic champion Dujardin walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, who has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris, has admitted to an \"error of judgement\" and said she was \"deeply ashamed\" of her actions.\n\nWith one Games about to start, France is already looking to host another Olympics, as the International Olympic Committee awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps.\n\nThe IOC handed the games to France but under the condition that Paris stumps up the required financial commitments.\n\nFrance is the only candidate to host the 2030 Games but the funding has been in question because there is no government in place following inconclusive snap elections.\n\nMacron told IOC members he would ask France's next prime minister to give a financial \"guarantee\" for hosting the Games.", "source": {"uri": "thesouthafrican.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The South African"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242085091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:35:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:35:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:34:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/07/25/sports/football-chaos-as-paris-olympics-kicks-off/1959730", "title": "Football chaos as Paris Olympics kicks off", "body": "Paris -- The sporting programme at the Paris Olympics endured a chaotic start on Wednesday (Thursday in Manila) as men's football kicked off while a huge police operation was put in place for Israel's first appearance at the Games.\n\nSwedish referee Glenn Nyberg speaks with Morocco's forward #09 Soufiane Rahimi (L) in the men's group B football match between Argentina and Morocco during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the Geoffroy-Guichard Stadium in Saint-Etienne on July 24, 2024. AFP PHOTO\n\nTwo days before the opening ceremony, Morocco beat Argentina 2-1 in Saint-Etienne, but only after a late equalizer for the South American side was disallowed and the final minutes were played out in an empty stadium following crowd trouble.\n\nArgentina thought they had escaped with a 2-2 draw when Cristian Medina scored in the 16th minute of added time.\n\nBut as their players celebrated, projectiles including bottles and plastic cups rained down from the stands and several spectators entered the pitch, with the referee promptly blowing the whistle.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nThe teams left the playing area, but the referee had not blown for full-time and the outcome of the match was unclear until the sides finally reappeared two hours later to play out three more minutes in a stadium that was by now emptied of spectators.\n\nMorocco's forward Soufiane Rahimi (2nd from right) celebrates with teammates after scoring his team's first goal in the men's group B football match between Argentina and Morocco during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the Geoffroy-Guichard Stadium in Saint-Etienne on July 24, 2024. AFP PHOTO Advertisement\n\nMedina's goal was eventually disallowed for offside following a review and Morocco celebrated a 2-1 win.\n\n\"It is a disgrace that this should happen and poison the tournament,\" said Argentina coach Javier Mascherano.\n\nIsrael's footballers later Wednesday took on Mali under the watchful eye of 1,000 police officers, with authorities erecting an \"anti-terrorist perimeter\" and braced for possible disruption around the stadium.\n\nIsrael's participation in Paris has been a key talking point in the run-up, with calls from the Palestine Olympic Committee and some left-wing French MPs for the country to be excluded over the Gaza war.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSome Palestinian and Israeli flags were flown with angry words exchanged amongst some fans at the Parc des Princes in Paris.\n\nHowever, French interior minister Gerald Darmanin said \"there has been no security problems to our knowledge\".\n\nA packed Stade de France cheered on Antoine Dupont -- arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games -- as he helped his team into the quarter-finals.\n\nA 12-12 draw with the United States was followed by a nervy 19-12 win over Uruguay.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn the same pool, double champions Fiji also made the knockout round with back-to-back wins over Uruguay and the United States.\n\nThe Olympic cauldron is lit outside Rice-Eccles Stadium during celebrations of the election of Salt Lake City as the 2034 host of Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games on July 24, 2024 in Salt Lake City, Utah. AFP PHOTO\n\nIOC warns Salt Lake\n\nAs the clock ticks down towards Friday's opening ceremony along the Seine, Olympic chiefs awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps and the 2034 event to Salt Lake City.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBut in a dramatic twist they warned the US city could be stripped of the Games if American authorities kept up their feud with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA).\n\nJohn Coates, the chairman of the IOC's legal commission, said the host city contract confirming Salt Lake's right to stage the Olympics had been altered to allow the IOC to strip it of the Games if US authorities did not respect the \"supreme authority\" of WADA.\n\nThe US anti-doping agency (USADA) has been a vocal critic of WADA for much of the past decade and tensions escalated this year after reports in April revealed that 23 Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance ahead of the Tokyo Olympics, but were subsequently cleared to compete at the Games.\n\nUSADA chief Travis Tygart accused Olympic bosses of \"stooping to threats\".\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Today's demonstration further showed that as it stands today, WADA is just a sport lapdog, and clean athletes have little chance,\" said Tygart.\n\nSecurity lockdown\n\nThe Olympics lost a top star when tennis world number one Jannik Sinner withdrew with tonsillitis, with the Italian admitting he was \"sad and disappointed\".\n\nPreparations for Friday's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athletes' parade along the River Seine.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAround 6,000-7,000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre (four-mile) stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500,000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments.\n\nThe area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced.\n\nBut videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers.\n\nAmerican rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame this Friday as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\nScandals\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse by one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, who has been suspended.\n\nThe film showed the three-time Olympic champion walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while apparently training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris.\n\nIn a further controversy, an assistant coach and an analyst with the Canadian women's football team were sent home after rivals were spied upon.\n\nThe analyst, 43-year-old Joey Lombardi, was also given a suspended eight-month prison sentence for flying a drone over a New Zealand training session.\n\nLombardi pleaded guilty when he appeared in court in Saint-Etienne on Wednesday, the court told AFP.\n\nThe assistant coach was Jasmine Mander, to whom Lombardi reported.", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Manila times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243034656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:21:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:21:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:20:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/newyork/news/olympics-schedule-2024-paris-games/", "title": "When do the Olympics start and end? See the schedule for the 2024 Paris Games.", "body": "The 2024 Paris Olympics are set to kick off soon, with a schedule full of sporting events. Here's everything you need to know about when this summer's Olympics will start and end.\n\nThe Olympics will officially open in Paris on the night of Friday, July 26 and continue through Sunday, Aug. 11, although some team events started on July 24. The July 26 opening ceremony will be held on the Seine river, which flows though Paris. The closing ceremony, which includes a parade of flags and athletes, will take place on Aug. 11.\n\nThe opening ceremony for the 2024 Summer Olympics will be unique. According to organizers, the July 26 event will be the first Olympic opening ceremony held outside of a stadium. The Tokyo opening ceremony last time around was held in a largely empty stadium because of the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nIn Paris, athletes will parade in boats down the Seine river. The flotilla will begin at 7:30 p.m. local time on Friday, July 26,, which is 1:30 p.m. Eastern in the U.S. and 10:30 a.m. on the West Coast.\n\nAn estimated 94 boats will travel along the almost four-mile route as part of the ceremony, with delegations and performers joining athletes on the Seine, according to organizers. Around 10,500 athletes representing 206 National Olympic Committees are taking part in the Games.\n\nAround 120 heads of state, royals and other leaders will also attend the opening ceremony.\n\nThe closing ceremony for the 2024 Summer Olympics will be on Sunday, Aug. 11, beginning at 2 p.m. Eastern, in the Stade de France. It will feature a parade of flags, a parade of athletes and victory ceremonies, among other events. The closing ceremony in Tokyo lasted for about three hours.\n\nArtistic gymnastics events are scheduled for July 27 to Aug. 1, and then again from Aug. 3-5. Rhythmic gymnastics events, a female-only event, are scheduled for Aug. 8-10. Artistic and rhythmic gymnastics test different skills and use different equipment.\n\nAll trampoline gymnastics events are scheduled for Aug. 2, the day starts with the women's qualifications, followed by the women's final. Then comes the men's qualifications and the men's final later on Aug. 2.\n\nWomen's artistic gymnastics, featuring athletes including U.S. star Simone Biles, involves four core events: beam, vault, uneven bars and floor exercise. Men's artistic gymnastics features eight events across six pieces of equipment: rings, vault, pommel horse, horizontal bar, parallel bars and floor exercise. There are two additional events to test the overall skill of the male gymnasts.\n\nThere are two categories of competition in Olympic rhythmic gymnastics, individual all-around women and group all-around women. It showcases skill, flexibility and musicality using balls, hoops, clubs and ribbons.\n\nSome who go to check the Olympics schedule for soccer may be confused: The sport is listed under football, as it is known in most of the world.\n\nThe events started before the official opening ceremony on July 26 because of the number of matches in the tournament. Matches are scheduled for most days during the Games, with the full listings and results available online.\n\nCompetition actually began two days before the opening ceremony, on July 24, with preliminary rounds in archery, soccer, handball and rugby. The swimming events will run during the first week of the Games from July 27 through Aug. 4, with track and field events taking place from July 1 to Aug. 11.\n\nThe marathon is traditionally the last athletic event.\n\nWhile a full schedule is available online, the Paris Games organizers note that it is subject to change.\n\nThere will be both live and tape-delayed coverage of the Olympics airing on TV. At least nine hours of coverage will be broadcast each day from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. ET on NBC and Telemundo. Some events will air on the USA Network, Golf Channel, CNBC and E!.\n\nPeacock will livestream events from the 2024 Olympics, including the opening and closing ceremonies and every Olympic basketball
