These boats will be equipped with cameras to allow television and online viewers to see the athletes up close.\n\n\"Winding their way from east to west, the 10,500 athletes will cross through the centre of Paris, the overall playing field for the Games on which these competitors will display their sporting prowess over the next 16 days.\n\nCASINO SPECIAL - BEST CASINO WELCOME OFFERS\n\n\"The parade will come to the end of its 6-kilometre route in front of the Trocadero, where the remaining elements of Olympic protocol and final shows will take place.\n\n\"Eighty giant screens and strategically placed speakers will allow everyone to enjoy the magical atmosphere of this show reverberating throughout the French capital.\n\n\"The opening ceremony for the Olympic Games Paris 2024 will be the largest in Games history. It will be open to all: residents from Paris and its region, as well as visitors from all over France and around the world.\n\n\"By opening with the parade of athletes, Paris 2024 is breaking with tradition.\n\n\"Athletes will be featured on stage during the introduction to and throughout the ceremony as part of Paris 2024's constant aim to hold Games created for and by athletes.\"\n\nIn a blow to organizers, the ceremony is allegedly struggling to sell out, as well as the showpiece Olympic event.\n\nIt is the third time that Paris will host the Summer Games, with the most recent edition coming exactly a century before - but it seems that excitement levels may be on the wane.\n\nThat is because \"hundreds of thousands of tickets\" remain unsold with just days left before it starts.\n\nThe Times state that between 500,000 and 600,000 tickets remain unsold.\n\nAnd, as of yesterday, they included both the men's and women's 100m finals.\n\nBoth of these two events are traditionally the hottest tickets at the Olympics and are sold out well in advance.\n\nTickets priced at \u00a3249 and \u00a3825 are still available for the Sunday 4 August session.\n\nAnd some for as low as \u00a3164 for the Saturday 3 August evening session, which includes the women's 100m final, are also still for sale.\n\nThe water quality of the Seine has also become a hot topic of discussion.\n\nIn 1923, swimming in the river was outlawed by the French government for a century due to its poor water quality and health hazards.\n\nOver \u00a31.2billion has been spent since 2016 in an attempt to clean it according to Sports Pro Media.\n\nDespite extensive efforts, including building a mega-basin designed to store waste and prevent the sewage system from spilling into the Let's dig through the details:\n\nThe opening ceremony kicks off at 6.30pm (Irish time) and is expected to last for at least three hours.\n\nFor the first time ever, the opening ceremony will not be held inside the host stadium - instead it will take place down the the River Seine.\n\nInstead of the Olympians and teams march through the Stade de France, instead they will be part of a river parade through the heart of the city.\n\nSpectators will be able to watch on from the banks and the quays of the famous river and the ambitious project is set to be the largest scale opening ceremony in history.\n\nApproximately 100 boats holding approximately 10,500 athletes will take part in the ceremony.\n\nThe boats will ultimately finish up at opposite the Trocadero just across from the Eiffel Tower where the Olympic flame will officially be lit.\n\nA big production requires big names to take part but so far the Olympic organising committee have kept details of the musical acts secret.\n\nThe likes of Celine Dion and Lady Gaga have already been spotted in Paris ahead of the ceremony but it is unclear if they will perform.\n\nThe Olympics are available on a variety of {"uri": "2024-07-433273099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:19:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:19:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:11:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.seattlepi.com/sports/article/how-to-watch-the-2024-olympics-opening-ceremony-19595676.php", "title": "How to watch the 2024 Olympics opening ceremony", "body": "The opening ceremony for the Paris Olympics is set for Friday.\n\nInstead of a traditional march into a stadium, about 10,500 athletes will parade on more than 90 boats on the Seine River for 6 kilometers (3.7 miles). This will start the ceremony, not mark the end of it, another break from tradition.\n\nThe ceremony starts at 1:30 p.m. EDT/7:30 p.m. CEST and is expected to last more than three hours.\n\nThe parade starts at the Austerlitz Bridge beside the Jardin des Plantes and follows the course of the Seine from east to west. It makes its way around two islands in the center of the city before passing under several bridges and gateways. Athletes aboard the boats will get glimpses of several Olympic venues including La Concorde Urban Park (3X3 basketball, breaking, BMX freestyle cycling, skateboarding), Invalides (archery, athletics -- marathon finish, road cycling -- time trial start) and the Grand Palais (fencing, taekwondo). The parade ends at the Iena Bridge, which links the Eiffel Tower on the left bank of the Seine to the Trocad\u00e9ro district on the right bank. The ceremony's finale is at the Trocad\u00e9ro. There, among other ceremonial procedures, French President Emmanuel Macron will deliver opening remarks.\n\nThe ceremony will air on NBC and stream on Peacock and NBC Olympic platforms -- NBCOlympics.com, NBC.com, NBC app, NBC Olympics app.\n\nA preview will air on NBC at noon EDT, with live coverage beginning at 1:30 p.m. and an enhanced prime-time encore at 7:30 p.m.\n\nAbout 220,000 invited and security-screened spectators are expected to fill the upper tiers of the Seine's banks, and an additional 104,000 paying spectators will watch from the lower riverside and around the Trocad\u00e9ro plaza.\n\nThose in Paris who could not get tickets will be able to watch the ceremony on 80 giant screens set up throughout the city.\n\nIn addition to the athletes who will participate in the parade, 3,000 dancers, artists and other athletes will be featured in the opening and closing ceremonies. Most of the entertainment acts remain under wraps. NBC News reported that Celine Dion and Lady Gaga have arrived in Paris amid speculation that one or both of the pop singers will perform at the opening ceremony.\n\nWell, onlookers and athletes will get wet since there is no roof over the Seine.\n\nAccording to the latest weather forecast, there is a small chance of rain. Meteo-France, the French weather service, is predicting overcast skies from midday onward, with light rain expected in the morning. The weather should improve in the afternoon, but the weather service warned Thursday that showers could hit the Paris region in the evening.\n\nIf it rains, the ceremony is expected to go on as {"uri": "8237518040", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-22", "time": "10:49:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-22T10:49:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-22T10:47:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Articles/2024/07/22/olympics", "title": "The unique route of the Paris Games opening ceremony will put security and logistics to the test", "body": "Crews built temporary bleachers this month along the Seine in preparation for the opening ceremony.getty images\n\nThe logistics struck Nicole Deal first. How would Team USA, the largest delegation in the Summer Olympics, navigate an unprecedented opening ceremony on the Seine?\n\nNext came the safety concerns, Deal's responsibility as chief of security and athlete services of the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee. It has taken years for her to feel comfortable with Paris 2024's plans as her team and federal officials worked closely with French security.\n\nWith the Paris Olympics set to open July 26, everyone from organizers and security officials, to hospitality providers and ceremony coordinators, feels the pressure of pulling off the event. The nearly four-hour ceremony along 6 kilometers of the famed river through Paris presents the biggest high-wire act of these Games, one that has taken years of planning to pull off.\n\n\"It's a balance of security,\" said Deal, \"and also the experience for the stakeholders that are going to be there. And they're finding that sweet spot right now.\"\n\nBefore the French can produce the promised spectacle through Paris, they must secure it. That's Herculean considering potential threats to the Games in France, which is no stranger to terrorist attacks. The ceremony will come less than two weeks after an assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump and with ongoing wars in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nTo secure the opening, local and federal law enforcement are planning around 45,000 officers, up from the 30,000 expected daily during the rest of the Olympics. The French military will bring in another 15,000 for the Games, and Paris 2024 will bring in up to 22,000 private security personnel.\n\nIn addition to security for the crowds at the opening ceremony, French officials need to vet residents and control access to buildings along the route.\n\n\"This would be no different as to when the pope comes somewhere and they do a parade route down the street or something,\" said Jim Morgan, who spent 24 years in the Secret Service and is now chief security officer at Concentric Advisors. \"That's exactly how they'll secure it. It's very challenging, but it is doable because they will treat it just like any other parade-type route that you would take, only it's on the water in boats.\"\n\nFor Deal, that will mean nesting Team USA's security plans with those of French authorities. She has worked closely with them and the State Department, which will have more than 70 agents on the ground with the U.S. delegation -- which includes 592 Olympic athletes -- throughout the Games.\n\nDeal, who spent 18 years as a special agent in the State Department's Bureau of Diplomatic Security, pointed to the French authorities' experience with the Tour de France, among other major sporting events. She said they have been in touch with the New York Police Department to discuss securing events such as New Year's Eve in Times Square, which draws around 1 million people. \"I'm feeling confident,\" she said in April. \"But it took a year and a half to get there.\"\n\nPart of that comes from Paris organizers adjusting the crowd size in January. Initially planned for 600,000 spectators, the ceremony will now accommodate around 300,000.\n\nRoughly 100,000 spectators will have paid tickets for the lower docks along the Seine, while another 220,000 will have free access by invitation to the upper docks. Security will be tight for both, and French authorities have said they will use artificial intelligence to monitor crowd surges.\n\n\"I was thrilled,\" Deal said of the adjustment in spectators. \"Because to me, that's understanding that you need to be nimble and you need to be flexible. And it's a balancing game. If you know you can't meet that security threshold, you've got to decrease the spectators.\"\n\n\u25a0 \u25a0 \u25a0 \u25a0\n\nThe security considerations will play a major role for the spectators who can attend in person, including the VIPs with the best seats for the spectacle.\n\nTo secure the Games, metro and car services will not run on the day of the opening. Sponsors, agencies and On Location -- the hospitality provider for the Games -- have built plans within those constraints.\n\nTheir message has been clear -- you'll have to be flexible, and you'll have to walk.\n\n\"I think generally, the sponsors get it. They just want us to provide a solution for their VIPs that is as painless as possible, accepting that it's a different experience and therefore there's going to be a compromise,\" said Michael Tonge, senior vice president of global sales at On Location. \"Nobody's going to drive up to the Trocadero and have a drop-off. It's just not going to happen.\"\n\nHospitality plans have largely been determined by which bank of the river spectators are staying on as it will not be possible to cross bridges, some of which are being used for hospitality, entertainment or broadcasts on the day of the ceremony.\n\nGMR Marketing, which has around 20 Olympic clients, said it is communicating the logistical and time constraints to clients and providing alternative hospitality lounges if they don't want to make the lengthy and involved commitment to go in person.\n\n\"It is top of mind on the safety of guests, getting them there, settled and getting them back and what that looks like on transport and so forth, because it could be a lot,\" said Corinne Holman-Martin, vice president of client and consulting services at GMR.\n\n\"Opening ceremony tends to be a bit of a long day or a long evening in general,\" Holman-Martin said. \"This has a different dynamic to it as well, so we've got to keep those things in mind and also keep the guest expectation to understand that because they're going to be one of 300,000-plus people.\"\n\nOn Location has offered several packages, from an open-air brasserie on a bridge to food and drinks in boats on the river. It also has hospitality lounges in venues within a 15-minute walk of the ceremony.\n\n\"It's once in a lifetime,\" Tonge said. \"It's never going to happen again in any way.\"\n\nThat is certainly the hope of the ceremony's creative team. Paris organizers selected Thomas Jolly, a French actor and theater director, to direct the opening ceremony. After that, little is known, with opening ceremony details treated like state secrets.\n\nWithin Paris 2024, the artists performing in the ceremony are referred to in code names of deceased singers. Marie-Catherine Ettori, director of ceremonies for Paris 2024, said organizers share documents with French authorities that outline generally what will happen in certain areas to allow them to secure the ceremony without sharing creative details.\n\n\"We felt that if you leave something very incredible at the beginning of the Games, for the Paralympics and for the Olympics, then there is something like high energy,\" Ettori said. \"To cross Paris in such configuration, we hope that will give [the athletes] some energy to create something wonderful in the sporting part of the Games.\"\n\nThe ceremony will use around 180 boats to progress through the 6-kilometer route, with organizers contracting with the tourist boats that work along the Seine. Around 10,000 athletes will make their way to the Trocadero, where part of the usual protocol and speeches will occur.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron and International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach are expected to be among the dozens of dignitaries at the Trocadero.\n\n\"Everybody from security, transportation down to the hospitality agency, On Location, everybody is thinking down to the one meter and the one minute, who needs to be where,\" said Christophe Dubi, the IOC's Olympic Games executive director.\n\n\"Is it challenging? The ultimate challenge. Is it the most rewarding? Most definitely.\"", "source": {"uri": "sportsbusinessjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "sportsbusinessjournal.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "rachel_axon@sportsbusinessjournal.com", "name": Instead, it will be a parade on the River Seine.\n\n\"Paris 2024 is breaking new ground by bringing sports into the city and the same will be true of the opening ceremony, set to be held in the heart of the city along its main artery: the Seine,\" the website says.\n\nWith the backdrop of the Eiffel Tower, the parade of 10,500 athletes will feature boats for each national delegation that float through the center of Paris and come to an end in front of the Trocad\u00e9ro.\n\nOpening ceremony flag bearers for the U.S. will be tennis player Coco Gauff and basketball player LeBron James, who were selected by their fellow Team USA athletes. This will be Gauff's first time competing in the Olympics; she was forced to drop out of the Tokyo Games in 2021 after testing positive for COVID-19. She is also the first tennis player selected to be the U.S. flag bearer at an Olympic opening ceremony. Watch the moment Gauff found out she was chosen.\n\n\"I just want to say thank you to my fellow team usa olympians/athletes for voting and choosing me for this incredible honor to be the flag bearer for the opening ceremony \u2764\ufe0f. Thank you so much. I am incredibly honored,\" Gauff posted on social media.\n\nThe Games arrive during a time of political uncertainty in America and follow a tumultuous two weeks that included an assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump and the sudden suspension of President Joe Biden's bid for reelection. It also follows France's snap legislative elections, called in June by French President Emmanuel Macron, which ended with a hung parliament and parties on the left and far right increasing their size and influence.\n\nAccording to a Seton Hall University sports poll, conducted at the end of June, Americans are more excited than in previous years to watch the 2024 Olympics.\n\nOver 1,600 adults across the country were asked if they were \"more excited to watch the opening ceremony than previous ones,\" 56% of self-described Olympic fans, 51% of sports fans, 59% of avid fans and 48% of casual fans said \"Yes.\"\n\nWhen compared to the 2021 Tokyo Summer Olympics, 59% of the general population and 75% of sports fans said they planned to watch at least part of the Paris Games, up from 49% of the general population and 65% of sports fans who said they would watch the Tokyo Games.\n\n\"Clearly, interest in the Paris 2024 Olympic games is the strongest in recent years,\" Seton Hall Professor Charles Grantham, director of the Center for Sport Management, said in a statement. \"Beyond being in Paris, one of the most visited and famous cities in the world, these games feature a better time difference to see more competitions live, and less off the field distractions such as the pandemic (Tokyo 2021) or human rights concerns (Beijing 2022).\"", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8242969048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:41:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:41:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:40:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/entertainment/3029755-paris-to-host-spectacular-seine-river-olympic-opening", "title": "Paris to Host Spectacular Seine River Olympic Opening | Entertainment", "body": "The Paris Olympics will commence with a unique opening ceremony on the Seine River. A floating parade featuring 85 boats and nearly 7,000 athletes will highlight the event. The ceremony promises dazzling performances and will prioritize security with a heavy police presence and strict measures.\n\nParis will officially kick off its Olympics extravaganza with an unprecedented opening ceremony on the river Seine on Friday.\n\nFor the first time, the Games' opening ceremony will not take place in a stadium. Instead, around 85 boats will carry nearly 7,000 athletes on a 6km floating parade on the Seine, at the heart of Paris. Departing from the Austerlitz bridge, they will sail past the Notre-Dame cathedral and arrive near the Eiffel Tower, after passing under bridges and gateways, including the Pont des Arts and Pont Neuf, and near many of the French capital's landmarks. The ceremony is due to start at 7.30 p.m. (1730 GMT) and last about three hours and 45 minutes.\n\nOrganisers have promised a show like no other, blending historic monuments, riverbanks, sky and water with music, dance, and art. Eighty giant screens will broadcast the event that is set to include a floating parade of athletes and artists with performances from building rooftops along the Seine. Some details remain secret, potentially featuring singers like Lady Gaga and Celine Dion, while Aya Nakamura is confirmed as part of the line-up. The show aims to be a grand fresco celebrating Paris, France, and the Olympics.\n\nOver 80 heads of state and 300,000 spectators are expected, with 222,000 receiving free invites and 104,000 purchasing tickets. Security is paramount with 2,000 private security staff, 45,000 police, snipers, anti-drone systems, and restricted access ensuring safety. France remains on high alert without specific terror threats identified. Past ceremonies include Tokyo's pandemic-affected 2020 Games, Rio's financially constrained 2016, London's extravagant 2012 show, and Beijing's grand 2008 event.", "source": {"uri": It will be held on the Seine River. The athletes will travel in around 100 boats along the river, passing through the iconic Parisian landmarks.\n\nThe ceremony will begin from Austerlitz Bridge, which is next to the Jardin des Plantes. Earlier this week, it was announced on TODAY that the basketball player, who has been leading Team USA in recent exhibition games, will receive the honor of carrying the United States flag. Teammate Steph Curry shared the exciting news to James and the rest of the USA Basketball players.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by TODAY (@todayshow)\n\nJames is already a gold medalist and this summer will mark his fourth Games. He previously competed for Team USA in 2004 and won a bronze medal before receiving gold medals in 2008 and 2012.\n\nThe two athletes who are chosen as flag bearers, one man and one woman, are voted by their fellow Olympic athletes. The other athlete who will carry the flag beside James has not been announced as of July 23.\n\nRead on to find out how you can watch James and the rest of Team USA make their grand entrance at the opening ceremony.\n\nWhere to the stream opening ceremony\n\nViewers can tune into the opening ceremony on NBC, Peacock, the NBC and NBC Olympic apps.\n\nAll live streams of Olympic events will be available throughout the Games on NBCOlympics.com, NBC.com, the NBC app and the NBC Olympics app. A complete schedule of the Games can be found here.\n\nMike Tirico, Kelly Clarkson and Peyton Manning will host NBC's broadcast of the opening ceremony while NBC Sports' Maria Taylor will be aboard the Team USA boat with the athletes.\n\nTODAY's Savannah Guthrie and Hoda Kotb will be on the bridge along the River Seine next to spectators, who will get to view the opening ceremony for the first time with no admission fee.\n\nWhat time does the opening ceremony start?\n\nThe opening ceremony begins Friday, July 26, at 10:30 a.m. PT/ 1:30 p.m. ET. It is expected to last approximately 4.5 hours. NBC's coverage, which includes a preview show, will start slightly earlier at 9 a.m. PT/ 12 p.m. ET.\n\nAn encore presentation will feature additional elements not in the original live show. The primetime encore of the opening ceremony will air at 7:30 p.m. ET, 6:30 p.m. CT, 6:30 p.m. MT and 7:30 p.m. PT.\n\nWhile past ceremonies have been held in stadiums, this time athletes will arrive via boat. They'll cruise down the River Seine, passing multiple Parisian landmarks, such as Notre-Dame and the Louvre. The procession begins under the Austerlitz Bridge next to Jardin des Plantes and ends near the Eiffel Tower at the Trocad\u00e9ro, where French president Emmanuel Macron will give a speech and the Olympic torch will be lit.\n\nHow long are the 2024 Paris Olympics?\n\nThe 2024 Paris Olympics will run from Friday, July 26, until Sunday, August 11, the day of the closing ceremony.\n\nThis article The Olympics opening ceremony will be held on Friday (July 26) and boast will be seen carrying the athletes of the nations that will be taking part in the mega event.", "source": {"uri": "timesnownews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TimesNow"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games_ceremony", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Olympic Games ceremony"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seine", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Seine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Olympic Games"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Modern_Pentathlon", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Modern Pentathlon", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Antiques_and_Collectibles/Pins", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Antiques and Collectibles/Pins", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally_Challenged", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally Challenged", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://static.tnn.in/thumb/msid-112015245,width-1280,height-720,resizemode-75/112015245.jpg?quality=100", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9751309", "eventUri": "eng-9751309", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-26", "textStart": 341, "textEnd": 348}], "sentiment": 0.003921568627450966, "wgt": 139, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8240088410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "20:34:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T20:34:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T20:33:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/olympics-just-days-away-france-180528925.html", "title": "With the Olympics just days away, France prepares for biggest security operation in the country's history", "body": "PARIS -- French President Emmanuel Macron and his government ministers have been relentlessly hitting the airwaves and speaking to reporters before Friday's Olympic opening ceremony.\n\nTheir message is simple: France is ready to keep the Paris Olympics safe.\n\nThese Games will see the biggest security operation in French history, officials said, with 45,000 police officers and gendarmes on duty Friday and 35,000 working every day after during the competition.\n\nSimon Riondet, chief of the Paris police's elite Recherche et d'Intervention (BRI) unit, made an analogy to sports, saying his officers are ready to perform -- even if they don't know exactly when they'll have to launch into action.\n\n\"That's what we're trying to do, be (ready) when we're going to be needed,\" Riondet told NBC News on Tuesday, moments after his team ran a drill to rescue hostages and kill a terrorist on a bus. \"And it's really hard because, contrary to the athletes, we don't have a date.\"\n\nInterior Minister G\u00e9rald Darmanin told France 2 Television on Sunday that there were no specific, detailed threats made against the opening ceremony, and confirmed it would go ahead as planned on the Seine.\n\nA new intelligence analysis center, created for these Games, will act as a hub for information gained from various French law enforcement agencies.\n\nRetired FBI agent Rob D'Amico, who worked on the 2002 Salt Lake City Olympics, said his best advice to the authorities in Paris would be to take any threat seriously, no matter how seemingly far-fetched.\n\n\"I talk about this with 9/11, we never thought that was going to happen -- so when we saw intel about it, it was dismissed,\" he said.\n\n\"So anytime something happens for the first time, it's really tough to get the intelligence community to really pay a lot of attention to it because it's never happened before.\"\n\nFriday's opening ceremony will be the first of its kind held outside the confines of a stadium, bringing a unique set of security challenges. The 10,500-athlete, 90-boat flotilla will travel a 3\u00bd-mile route down the Seine through the middle of Paris.\n\nA diplomatic Riondet said he didn't mind having to prep for the unprecedented event.\n\n\"Of course, it's an additional challenge,\" he said. \"We train frequently on the Seine and I know that it's going to be very, very nice. If you have the chance to be on a boat, on the Seine, it's quite tremendous, seeing all the buildings. The people will be able to see athletes in a way they've never experienced.\"\n\nThe Olympics come to Paris almost nine years after coordinated terrorist attacks cost the lives of 130 people in the deadliest attack ever in peacetime France.\n\nThere have been about 50 terrorist attacks stopped by intelligence services since 2017, officials said.\n\nOf the 45,000 law enforcement agents who will be on duty Friday, there will be 650 members of elite tactical units, snipers and hostage specialists. There'll also be 22,000 private security contractors working during the opening ceremony Friday, officials said.\n\nTo enter any part of the control zone, whether its blocks away from an Olympic event venue or the Seine River, getting through checkpoints can take 20 to 30 minutes depending on traffic and time of day. Police check everyone's credentials and match them with an ID.\n\nOver 12-foot-high wooden planks are blocking off popular tourist sites like the Champs de Mars in front of the Eiffel Tower and the grounds by Les Invalides ahead of the games.\n\nOn Tuesday, there's also a more visible military presence as the \"Vigipirate\" -- the country's counterterrorism unit -- have begun patrolling the streets along with police and the Gendarmerie.\n\nA security perimeter will prevent vehicles and most pedestrians from vast swaths of the city by the Seine, which cuts across Paris. Subway stations and bridges across the river will be closed.\n\nFrench authorities carried out background checks on a million people linked to the Games, including job applicants, volunteers, competitors, coaches and staff, journalists and security contractors, leading to 4,350 identified as potential security threats, officials said.\n\nD'Amico, the retired FBI agent, said he doesn't envy Paris security officials, running the Olympics during this fraught time in world history with nearby wars in the Middle East and Eastern Europe.\n\n\"Everyone is going to look at the Olympics to make a name for themselves and that's why it is one of the biggest targets out there,\" said D'Amico, who now runs a security consulting company in Florida.\n\nSo far, the only known plot against the Olympics was foiled back in May by France's domestic intelligence agency, the Direction G\u00e9n\u00e9rale de la S\u00e9curit\u00e9 Int\u00e9rieure (DGSI).\n\nA Chechen man was arrested in Saint-Etienne and suspected of planning an attack on the city's soccer stadium during a competition. The Islamic State Khorasan Province group, the Central Asian offshoot of the Islamic State terrorist group, was behind the plot, officials have said.\n\nProtecting air space above the Games will be a top priority and Prime Minister Gabriel Attal visited a military air base Tuesday to inspect anti-drone systems.\n\nAbout six drones are now being intercepted near Olympic sites every day, according to Attal.\n\nA no-fly zone will be enforced up to 93 miles outside the center of Paris on Friday night.\n\n\"Nothing can be allowed to get past us,\" Attal told reporters in V\u00e9lizy-Villacoublay, southwest of Paris. France's military has prepared to deploy systems that can detect, jam, and intercept drones.\n\nSecurity will be high underwater as well, with 100 mine-clearing divers on duty.\n\n\"We are preparing for something that isn't fully anticipated,\" Riondet said. \"So, we've anticipated thousands of scenarios and that we are ready to take over on a scenario that wasn't expected.\"", "source": {"uri": This will start the ceremony, not mark the end of it, another break from tradition.", "source": {"uri": "goskagit.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "goSkagit"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@goskagit.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games_ceremony", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Olympic Games ceremony"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seine", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Seine"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Watches", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Jewelry/Watches", "wgt": 13}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Stadiums", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Stadiums", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Collecting/Clocks_and_Watches", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Collecting/Clocks and Watches", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally_Challenged", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally Challenged", "wgt": 19}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Olympics", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Olympics", "wgt": 20}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/goskagit.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/02/a02adace-ea57-5c0a-b763-53bd34d00d32/669e647e04959.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9751309", "eventUri": "eng-9751309", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.003921568627450966, "wgt": 139, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8240818061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:15:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:15:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:14:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.yenisafak.com/en/news/summer-edition-of-olympic-games-returns-to-paris-after-100-years-3687974", "title": "Summer edition of Olympic Games returns to Paris after 100 years | News", "body": "Paris 2024, world's biggest sporting event, to begin on July 26 with opening ceremony on River Seine\n\nThe 2024 Summer Olympics will see the Games return to Paris after a century, with the French capital previously hosting the world's biggest sporting event in 1900 and 1924.\n\nThe 33rd edition of the Summer Olympics will kick off on Friday, with an opening ceremony on the River Seine, and run until Aug. 11.\n\nThe closing ceremony will take place at the Stade de France.\n\nSince 1896, the modern Games have been held every four years aside from 1916, 1940 and 1944, when they were canceled because of World Wars I and II.\n\nAthletes who win will take with them a part of the Eiffel Tower, as the medals feature fragments of iron sourced from the iconic structure.\n\nThe medalists will display an authentic segment of the Eiffel Tower on their chests, as each medal will feature a central piece of iron weighing 18 grams.\n\nThe metal comes from parts of the monument's structure removed during renovation work during the 20th century.\n\n- Candidacy process\n\nOn Sept. 13, 2015, France formally submitted its bid to host the 2024 Summer Olympic Games.\n\nIt was endorsed by Denis Masseglia, then-president of the French Olympic Committee (CNOSF), and Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo.\n\nAt the time, Paris, which had set aside a budget of \u20ac6.2 billion ($6.7 billion), for the Games, was considered a more formidable contender in 2015 compared to its competitors.\n\nParis had last hosted the Olympics in 1924 and had bid for the Games in 1992, 2008 and 2012.\n\nAfter Hamburg, Budapest and Rome withdrew their bids, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) urged Los Angeles and Paris to reach a compromise.\n\nThe Committee proposed that Los Angeles host the 2028 Olympic Games and offered $1.8 billion in support for their preparation.\n\nWith Los Angeles accepting this proposal, Paris then agreed to host the 2024 Summer Olympics.\n\n- Paris 2024 Olympic mascot\n\nThe Organizing Committee unveiled the designs for the mascots of the Olympic and Paralympic Games on Nov. 14, 2022.\n\nIts name and design were chosen as symbols of freedom and to represent allegorical figures of the French Republic.\n\nThe mascot's eyes were designed to be both mischievous and expressive and were also compared to the cockade of France, the French national ornament.\n\nIts features, attire and gestures reflect the mascot's passion for sports.\n\n- Olympic torch\n\nThe Olympic torch relay, a central tradition of the event, was introduced at the 1936 Berlin Summer Games.\n\nThe Paris 2024 Games torch was designed by French designer Mathieu Lehanneur.\n\nCarried by 10,000 people over thousands of miles, the torch, crafted from metal by steel giant Arcelor Mittal, resembles an oval iron pipe with a rounded center.\n\nUpon its arrival, the torch will have been carried to more than 400 locations, including France's overseas territories, until the opening of the event on July 26.\n\n- Russian, Belarussian athletes to compete as neutrals\n\nAccording to the International Olympic Committee, athletes from Russia and Belarus will compete under neutral status and will not participate in the opening ceremony.\n\nThe flags, emblems and anthems of Russia and Belarus will not be used, and athletes from these countries must adhere to the same anti-doping regulations as all other participants.\n\nNo officials from the governments of either country will be invited or accredited as part of the games.\n\nThe closing "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/let-games-begin-rugby-football-092118112.html", "title": "Football chaos as Paris Olympics kicks off", "body": "The sporting programme at the Paris Olympics endured a chaotic start on Wednesday as men's football kicked off and a huge police operation was put in place for Israel's first appearance at the Games.\n\nTwo days before the opening ceremony, Morocco beat Argentina 2-1 in Saint-Etienne, but only after a late equaliser for the South American side was disallowed and the final minutes were played out in an empty stadium following crowd trouble.\n\nArgentina thought they had escaped with a 2-2 draw when Cristian Medina scored in the 16th minute of added time.\n\nBut as their players celebrated, projectiles including bottles and plastic cups rained down from the stands and several spectators entered the pitch, with the referee promptly blowing the whistle.\n\nThe teams left the playing area, but the referee had not blown for full-time and the outcome of the match was unclear until the sides finally reappeared two hours later to play out three more minutes in a stadium that was by now emptied of spectators.\n\nMedina's goal was eventually disallowed for offside following a review and Morocco celebrated a 2-1 win.\n\nIsrael's footballers later Wednesday take on Mali under the watchful eye of 1,000 police officers, with authorities erecting an \"anti-terrorist perimeter\" and bracing for possible disruption around the stadium.\n\nIsrael's participation in Paris has been a key talking point in the run-up, with calls from the Palestine Olympic Committee and some left-wing French MPs for the country to be excluded over the Gaza war.\n\nA packed Stade de France cheered on Antoine Dupont -- arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games -- but he was unable to lead the hosts to victory in a 12-12 draw with the United States.\n\n\"It's always a lot of emotion when you play with all your supporters so it's important to deal with that and to be better even with the pressure,\" admitted the 27-year-old.\n\nAustralia laid down a marker to France and double champions Fiji with a 21-14 win over Samoa at a packed Stade de France.\n\n- IOC warns Salt Lake -\n\nAs the clock ticks down towards Friday's opening ceremony along the Seine, Olympic chiefs awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps and the 2034 event to Salt Lake City.\n\nBut in a dramatic twist they warned the US city could be stripped of the Games if American authorities kept up their feud with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA).\n\nJohn Coates, the chairman of the IOC's legal commission, said the host city contract confirming Salt Lake's right to stage the Olympics had been altered to allow the IOC to strip it of the Games if US authorities did not respect the \"supreme authority\" of WADA.\n\nThe US anti-doping agency (USADA) has been a vocal critic of WADA for much of the past decade and tensions escalated this year after reports in April revealed that 23 Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance ahead of the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, but were subsequently cleared to compete at the Games.\n\nUSADA chief Travis Tygart accused Olympic bosses of \"stooping to threats\".\n\n\"Today's demonstration further showed that as it stands today, WADA is just a sport lapdog, and clean athletes have little chance,\" said Tygart.\n\n- Security lockdown -\n\nThe Olympics lost a top star when tennis world number one Jannik Sinner withdrew with tonsillitis with the Italian admitting he was \"sad and disappointed\".\n\nPreparations for Friday's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athletes' parade along the River Seine.\n\nAround 6,000-7,000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre (four-mile) stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500,000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments.\n\nThe area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced.\n\nBut videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers.\n\nAmerican rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame this Friday as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\n- Scandals -\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse by one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, who has been suspended.\n\nThe film showed the three-time Olympic champion walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while apparently training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris.\n\nIn a further scandal, an assistant coach and an analyst with the Canadian women's football team were sent home for their part in spying on rivals.\n\nThe analyst, 43-year-old Joey Lombardi, was also given a suspended eight-month prison sentence for flying a drone over a New Zealand training session.\n\nLombardi pleaded guilty when he appeared in court in Saint-Etienne on Wednesday, the court told So, with rumours swirling of appearances by Celine Dion and Lady Gaga, plans for boats full of athletes and a huge city-wide after-party, here is everything you need to know about the opening ceremony.\n\nRecommended:\n\nEverything you need to know about the Paris 2024 Olympics\n\nParis 2024 Olympics opening ceremony: start time, date and everything you need to know\n\nHow to get around during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games\n\nParis 2024 Olympics QR Code: how to apply and the zone system explained\n\nThe ceremony will begin at 7.30pm CEST (which is 6.30pm BST, 12.30pm CDT and 10.30pm PDT). The Summer Games will officially be launched at 8.24pm CEST, or 20.24 on a 24-hour clock - pretty clever, eh?\n\nFor the first time ever, the ceremony won't be held in a stadium. Instead, planners have spent months organising a performance on the Seine, with boats for each national delegation. The parade will begin at the Austerlitz Bridge and culminate its 6km-long route in front of the Trocad\u00e9ro.\n\nThe whole shebang has been kept largely under wraps, but that hasn't stopped rumours swirling about who is expected to perform at the opening ceremony. Two of the most exciting anticipated named include none other than Celine Dion and Lady Gaga.\n\nAya Nakamura, the most listened-to French singer worldwide, is also expected to perform at the opening ceremony. Stay tuned for updates on the line-up.\n\nIt will last three and a half hours, from 7.30pm to 11pm CEST. But the night doesn't have to end there - bars across Paris have been granted a special permit to stay open all night to celebrate the launch of the competition. You can read more about that here.\n\nIf you're watching in France, France T\u00e9l\u00e9vision, the national broadcaster, is the channel to hop to. In the UK (and if you've got a TV licence), the BBC is showing Olympics coverage and in the US, NBC is set to air at least nine hours of coverage a day.\n\nThe Olympics also has its own streaming channel for those watching online. Read our full guide on how to watch the Olympics here.\n\nThe tickets were being sold in six categories, A, B, C, D, E+ and E, with prices ranging from \u20ac90-\u20ac2,700.\n\nWant to get your hands on some last-minute tickets? Well, earlier this week we reported that 4,000 tickets are still available for the opening ceremony. Many of those are likely to have sold by now, and while there are still tickets available, they start from an eye-watering \u20ac1,800. {"uri": "8241990222", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:45:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:45:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:45:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/687327/sports/paris-olympics-kicks-off-with-chaos-and-crowd-trouble", "title": "Paris Olympics kicks off with chaos and crowd trouble", "body": "The sporting programme at the Paris Olympics endured a chaotic start on Wednesday as men's football kicked off and a huge police operation.\n\nTwo days before the opening ceremony, Morocco beat Argentina 2-1 in Saint-Etienne, but only after a late equaliser for the South American side was disallowed and the final minutes were played out in an empty stadium following crowd trouble.\n\nArgentina thought they had escaped with a 2-2 draw when Cristian Medina scored in the 16th minute of added time. But as their players celebrated, projectiles including bottles and plastic cups rained down from the stands and several spectators entered the pitch, with the referee promptly blowing the whistle.\n\nThe teams left the playing area, but the referee had not blown for full-time and the outcome of the match was unclear until the sides finally reappeared two hours later to play out three more minutes in a stadium that was by now emptied of spectators. Medina's goal was eventually disallowed for offside following a review and Morocco celebrated a 2-1 win.\n\nSilver medallists in Tokyo three years ago, Spain opened their bid for gold with a 2-1 win over Uzbekistan in Group C at the Parc des Princes in Paris. The Spain team featured two members of their Euro 2024-winning squad in Alex Baena and Fermin Lopez, but it was Marc Pubill who gave them the lead just before the half-hour mark.\n\nUzbekistan drew level from the penalty spot in first-half added time following a foul by Pau Cubarsi, with Roma forward Eldor Shomurodov converting the kick. Sergio Gomez then had a penalty saved early in the second half, but the former Manchester City player netted Spain's winner just after the hour mark.\n\nGroup rivals Egypt and the Dominican Republic drew 0-0. The pick of last night's later games saw hosts France face the United States in Marseille in Group A, with Thierry Henry's team hoping to win a medal despite failing in their attempts to enrol the services of Kylian Mbappe. New Zealand defeated Guinea 2-1 in the same section with Plymouth Argyle's Ben Waine getting the winner. Japan beat 10-man Paraguay 5-0 in Group D.\n\nA packed Stade de France cheered on Antoine Dupont - arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games - but he was unable to lead the hosts to victory in a 12-12 draw with the United States. \"It's always a lot of emotion when you play with all your supporters so it's important to deal with that and to be better even with the pressure,\" admitted the 27-year-old. Australia laid down a marker to France and double champions Fiji with a 21-14 win over Samoa at a packed Stade de France.\n\nAs the clock ticks down towards tomorrow's opening ceremony along the Seine, Olympic chiefs awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps and the 2034 event to Salt Lake City. But in a dramatic twist they warned the US city could be stripped of the Games if American authorities kept up their feud with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA).\n\nJohn Coates, the chairman of the IOC's legal commission, said the host city contract confirming Salt Lake's right to stage the Olympics had been altered to allow the IOC to strip it of the Games if US authorities did not respect the \"supreme authority\" of WADA. The US anti-doping agency (USADA) has been a vocal critic of WADA for much of the past decade and tensions escalated this year after reports in April revealed that 23 Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance ahead of the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, but were subsequently cleared to compete at the Games.\n\nUSADA chief Travis Tygart accused Olympic bosses of \"stooping to threats\". \"Today's demonstration further showed that as it stands today, WADA is just a sport lapdog, and clean athletes have little chance,\" said Tygart.\n\nThe Olympics lost a top star when tennis world number one Jannik Sinner withdrew with tonsillitis with the Italian admitting he was \"sad and disappointed\".\n\nPreparations for tomorrow's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athletes' parade along the River Seine. Around 6,000-7,000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre (four-mile) stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500,000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments. The area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced. But videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers. American rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame tomorrow as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse by one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, who has been suspended. The film showed the three-time Olympic champion walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while apparently training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris. In a further scandal, an assistant coach and an analyst with the Canadian women's football team were sent home for their part in spying on rivals. The analyst, 43-year-old Joey Lombardi, was also given a suspended eight-month prison sentence for flying a drone over a New Zealand training session.\n\nLombardi pleaded guilty when he appeared in court in Saint-Etienne on Wednesday, the court said. The assistant coach was Jasmine Mander, to whom Lombardi reported.", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gulf-Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Paris Olympics kicks off", "body": "Empty feeling: Morocco's players and staff celebrate at the end of the match with Argentina\n\nThe sporting programme at the Paris Olympics endured a chaotic start on Wednesday as men's football kicked off and a huge police operation was put in place for Israel's first appearance at the Games.\n\nTwo days before the opening ceremony, Morocco beat Argentina 2-1 in Saint-Etienne, but only after a late equaliser for the South American side was disallowed and the final minutes were played out in an empty stadium following crowd trouble.\n\nArgentina thought they had escaped with a 2-2 draw when Cristian Medina scored in the 16th minute of added time.\n\nBut as their players celebrated, projectiles including bottles and plastic cups rained down from the stands and several spectators entered the pitch, with the referee promptly blowing the whistle.\n\nThe teams left the playing area, but the referee had not blown for full-time and the outcome of the match was unclear until the sides finally reappeared two hours later to play out three more minutes in a stadium that was by now emptied of spectators.\n\nMedina's goal was eventually disallowed for offside following a review and Morocco celebrated a 2-1 win.\n\nIsrael's footballers later Wednesday take on Mali under the watchful eye of 1,000 police officers, with authorities erecting an \"anti-terrorist perimeter\" and bracing for possible disruption around the stadium.\n\nIsrael's participation in Paris has been a key talking point in the run-up, with calls from the Palestine Olympic Committee and some left-wing French MPs for the country to be excluded over the Gaza war.\n\nA packed Stade de France cheered on Antoine Dupont -- arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games -- but he was unable to lead the hosts to victory in a 12-12 draw with the United States.\n\n\"It's always a lot of emotion when you play with all your supporters so it's important to deal with that and to be better even with the pressure,\" admitted the 27-year-old.\n\nAustralia laid down a marker to France and double champions Fiji with a 21-14 win over Samoa at a packed Stade de France.\n\n- IOC warns Salt Lake -\n\nAs the clock ticks down towards Friday's opening ceremony along the Seine, Olympic chiefs awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps and the 2034 event to Salt Lake City.\n\nBut in a dramatic twist they warned the US city could be stripped of the Games if American authorities kept up their feud with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA).\n\nJohn Coates, the chairman of the IOC's legal commission, said the host city contract confirming Salt Lake's right to stage the Olympics had been altered to allow the IOC to strip it of the Games if US authorities did not respect the \"supreme authority\" of WADA.\n\nThe US anti-doping agency (USADA) has been a vocal critic of WADA for much of the past decade and tensions escalated this year after reports in April revealed that 23 Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance ahead of the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, but were subsequently cleared to compete at the Games.\n\nUSADA chief Travis Tygart accused Olympic bosses of \"stooping to threats\".\n\n\"Today's demonstration further showed that as it stands today, WADA is just a sport lapdog, and clean athletes have little chance,\" said Tygart.\n\nMore from this section New lawsuit accuses MTA of cutting bus services Oval Invincibles Vs Birmingham Phoenix - Playing Xis, Head To Head, Venue Details Wife of New York Yankees executive dies after being found unresponsive at home - Security lockdown -\n\nThe Olympics lost a top star when tennis world number one Jannik Sinner withdrew with tonsillitis with the Italian admitting he was \"sad and disappointed\".\n\nPreparations for Friday's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athletes' parade along the River Seine.\n\nAround 6,000-7,000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre (four-mile) stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500,000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments.\n\nThe area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced.\n\nBut videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers.\n\nAmerican rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame this Friday as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\n- Scandals -\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse by one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, who has been suspended.\n\nThe film showed the three-time Olympic champion walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while apparently training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris.\n\nIn a further scandal, an assistant coach and an analyst with the Canadian women's football team were sent home for their part in spying on rivals.\n\nThe analyst, 43-year-old Joey Lombardi, was also given a suspended eight-month prison sentence for flying a drone over a New Zealand training session.\n\nLombardi pleaded guilty when he appeared in court in Saint-Etienne on Wednesday, the court told AFP.\n\nThe assistant coach was Jasmine Mander, to whom Lombardi reported.\n\nric-jw/gj/dj/jc", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8242558249", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:23:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:23:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:23:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/emmanuel-macron-ap-seine-river-nbc-grand-palais-b2585598.html", "title": "How to watch the 2024 Olympics opening ceremony", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nThe opening ceremony for the Paris Olympics is set for Friday.\n\nInstead of a traditional march into a stadium, about 10,500 athletes will parade on more than 90 boats on the Seine River for 6 kilometers (3.7 miles). This will start the ceremony, not mark the end of it, another break from tradition.\n\nWhat time does the opening ceremony start?\n\nThe ceremony starts at 1:30 p.m. EDT/7:30 p.m. CEST and is expected to last more than three hours.\n\nWhere is the opening ceremony be ing held?\n\nThe parade starts at the Austerlitz Bridge beside the Jardin des Plantes and follows the course of the Seine from east to west. It makes its way around two islands in the center of the city before passing under several bridges and gateways. Athletes aboard the boats will get glimpses of several Olympic venues including La Concorde Urban Park (3X3 basketball, breaking, BMX freestyle cycling, skateboarding), Invalides (archery, athletics -- marathon finish, road cycling -- time trial start) and the Grand Palais (fencing, taekwondo). The parade ends at the Iena Bridge, which links the Eiffel Tower on the left bank of the Seine to the Trocad\u00e9ro district on the right bank. The ceremony's finale is at the Trocad\u00e9ro. There, among other ceremonial procedures, French President Emmanuel Macron will deliver opening remarks.\n\nHow can I watch t he opening ceremony?\n\nThe ceremony will air on NBC and stream on Peacock and NBC Olympic platforms -- NBCOlympics.com, NBC.com, NBC app, NBC Olympics app.\n\nA preview will air on NBC at noon EDT, with live coverage beginning at 1:30 p.m. and an enhanced prime-time encore at 7:30 p.m.\n\nAbout 220,000 invited and security-screened spectators are expected to fill the upper tiers of the Seine's banks, and an additional 104,000 paying spectators will watch from the lower riverside and around the Trocad\u00e9ro plaza.\n\nThose in Paris who could not get tickets will be able to watch the ceremony on 80 giant screens set up throughout the city.\n\nWho is performing at the opening ceremony?\n\nIn addition to the athletes who will participate in the parade, 3,000 dancers, artists and other athletes will be featured in the opening and closing ceremonies. Most of the entertainment acts remain under wraps. NBC News reported that Celine Dion and Lady Gaga have arrived in Paris amid speculation that one or both of the pop singers will perform at the opening ceremony.\n\n___\n\nAP Summer Olympics: {"uri": "8241030595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:25:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:25:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:24:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/let-the-games-begin-rugby-football-kick-off-paris-2024/article_4279d5a1-8f70-578a-8dd1-c94bea2a7288.html", "title": "Let the Games begin! Rugby, football kick off Paris 2024", "body": "Britain's Charlotte Dujardin has three Olympic gold medals in dressage\n\nFootball and Rugby Sevens kick off the sport at the Paris Olympics Wednesday, two days before the opening ceremony, featuring a top French star and a huge police presence for Israel's first appearance.\n\nIsrael's footballers take on Mali in the men's competition, under the watchful eye of 1,000 police officers, with authorities erecting an \"anti-terrorist perimeter\" and bracing for possible disruption around the stadium.\n\nA French police source told AFP it was possible that \"people shout insults from the stands\" or that there is \"whistling and flags shown during the hymns, for example.\"\n\nIsrael's participation in Paris has been a key talking point in the run-up, with calls from the Palestinian Olympic Committee and some left-wing French MPs for the country to be excluded over the Gaza war.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stressed the Israeli athletes were \"welcome in our country\", adding it was \"France's responsibility to provide them with security.\"\n\nMeanwhile, a packed Stade de France will cheer on Antoine Dupont -- arguably the world's best rugby player and a pin-up of the Paris Games -- as the Rugby Sevens tournament starts.\n\nThe electric Dupont is the biggest draw for the 555,000 fans expected over the six days of rugby action, but France will have their work cut out to stop double Olympic champions Fiji.\n\nFrance and Fiji are in the same pool and will play the United States and Uruguay, before the pair face each other in a mouthwatering clash on Thursday.\n\nOthers to watch in the wide-open competition are traditional rugby powers New Zealand, Australia, Argentina, and Ireland.\n\n- 'There's no one' -\n\nPreparations for Friday's historic opening ceremony were in full swing with an unprecedented security operation for the athlete's parade along the River Seine.\n\nAround 6,000-7,000 athletes are set to sail down a six-kilometre (four-mile) stretch of the river towards the Eiffel Tower, on 85 barges and boats.\n\nUp to 500,000 people are set to watch in person from specially built stands, on the river banks and from the overlooking balconies and apartments.\n\nThe area around the river has been locked down before the ceremony, with snipers positioned along the route and frogmen deployed to prevent a waterborne attack.\n\nMore from this section 'Everything is ruined.' Clifton residents near Route 3 fatal crash site raise concerns over spilled chemicals Abdul 'Duke' Fakir of The Four Tops dead at 88 J&K: Terrorists Attack Security Post Near Shaurya Chakra Awardee's Home in Rajouri | Soldier Injured\n\nThe entertainment line-up for the ceremony, the first time a Summer Olympics has opened outside the main stadium, is yet to be fully announced.\n\nBut videos posted online showing US pop star Lady Gaga in Paris sparked rumours she will be among the performers.\n\nAmerican rapper Snoop Dogg will carry the Olympic flame this Friday as it makes its final rounds before the ceremony.\n\nSome Paris business owners grumbled the security measures were hurting their bottom line.\n\n\"We were told there would be loads of people during the Olympics and even before. But in fact, no. There's no one,\" Jonas Seignovert, manager of the Eugene restaurant, told AFP.\n\nIn the first scandal of the Games, a video emerged showing the mistreatment of a horse that led to one of Britain's most decorated Olympians, dressage specialist Charlotte Dujardin, being ejected from the Paris Games.\n\nThe video showed three-time Olympic champion Dujardin walking alongside a horse and repeatedly whipping the animal while training a young rider.\n\nDujardin, 39, who has won six Olympic medals and was aiming to become Britain's most successful female Olympian by winning further medals in Paris, has admitted to an \"error of judgement\" and said she was \"deeply ashamed\" of her actions.\n\n- Financial guarantees' -\n\nWith one Games about to start, France is already looking to host another Olympics, as the International Olympic Committee awarded the 2030 Winter Games to the French Alps.\n\nThe IOC handed the games to France but under the condition that Paris stumps up the required financial commitments.\n\nFrance is the only candidate to host the 2030 Games but the funding has been in question because there is no government in place following inconclusive snap elections.\n\nMacron told IOC members he would ask France's next prime minister to give a financial \"guarantee\" for hosting the Games.\n\nburs-ric/gj", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8240906012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:10:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:10:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:09:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.bpr.org/npr-news/2024-07-24/8-storylines-to-follow-as-the-paris-summer-olympics-get-underway", "title": "8 storylines to follow as the Paris Summer Olympics get underway", "body": "After COVID-19 pandemic restrictions kept spectators away for the last two Olympic Games (in Beijing and Tokyo), the French capital has prepared to welcome back crowds with a splash: the public will be treated to a unique opening ceremony on the iconic River Seine.\n\nThe outdoor ceremony -- set to be the largest one yet, measured by audience and geographical sprawl -- kicks off 16 days of sporting events held across the city and beyond.\n\nOutside of Paris, the historic Palace of Versailles will host equestrian events, while surfing will take place some 10,000 miles away in Teahupo'o, Tahiti.\n\nContinuing its streak of domination at the Summer Games, the United States is expected to collect the most medals in Paris, followed by China, Great Britain, France and then Australia. Russia, meanwhile -- typically a top contender -- is sending a very small number of athletes to Paris following consequences related to their country's doping and its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nHere's what else to know ahead of the Games before the opening ceremony on Friday.\n\nClose to 100 boats carrying more than 10,000 athletes and performers will glide down a 3.7-mile stretch of the River Seine during the opening ceremony on July 26. It's the first time in the history of the modern Olympics that's being held outside of a stadium, officials say.\n\nThe open-air event is expected to draw some 300,000 spectators -- most of whom will pay no admission fee to watch the parade from the river's upper embankments.\n\nThe parade will travel east to west, starting at Austerlitz Bridge, and then pass by major landmarks and event venues like the Grand Palais. The parade is set to end at the Pont d'I\u00e9na bridge before a finale show at the Trocad\u00e9ro opposite the Eiffel Tower.\n\nTony Estanguet, president of the Paris Games organizing committee, described the vision for the ceremony when the plan was announced in 2021.\n\n\"The entire city has been turned into a vast Olympic stadium. The Seine represents the track, and the quays the spectators' stands,\" Estanguet said.\n\nThe parade's route also offers a sightseeing tour of some of the temporary sports venues, including an outdoor arena abutting the Eiffel Tower where beach volleyball games will take place.\n\nThere's also the matter of the Seine as a competition venue. In the run-up to the games, a question has plagued officials: Will the Seine be swimmable in time for the Olympics? The sewage-polluted waters have been a hurdle to the city's ambitious goal to hold the swim leg of the triathlon in the famous river where swimming has been historically banned.\n\nRecent testing of the water has turned up unsafe levels of E. coli bacteria caused by fecal matter, but tests earlier this month showed acceptable bacteria levels. In an effort to silence skeptics, last week Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo followed through on her promise to take a dip in the Seine and declared the waters perfectly safe.\n\nFollowing the previous Summer Games' addition of skateboarding and surfing, another sport with counterculture roots will take the Olympics stage for the first time in Paris. Breaking -- best known to the uninitiated as \"break-dancing\" -- is a dance style said to have originated in the 1970s from the streets of New York City's South Bronx and inspired by the break beats and hip-hop tracks played by DJs and MCs. But the athleticism involved in the art form -- head-spins, backflips and other acrobatics -- is undeniable.\n\nBreaking became more mainstream in the 1990s as it entered pop culture and expanded in popularity through international competition. And in 2016, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) added breaking to the 2018 Youth Olympic Games in Buenos Aires.\n\nAlthough it's an American export, other countries including Japan, Canada and The Netherlands boast talent that's been known to surpass the U.S. competitively.\n\nIn Paris, 16 b-boys (male breakers) and 16 b-girls will go head to head in separate battles at Place de la Concorde, an outdoor public square. The women's competition is set for Aug. 9 and men's is on Aug. 10. On Team USA, look out for medal contenders Victor Montalvo and Grace \"Sunny\" Choi.\n\nThe same U.S. women's gymnastics team that took home a silver medal at the Tokyo Games all-around final in 2021 is hoping to rewrite their Olympic ending in Paris.\n\nThree years ago, Biles, who at 27 is the most decorated gymnast of all time, came down with a case of the \"twisties,\" a debilitating psychological affliction that forced her to pull out of several events to focus on her mental health. In her place, Suni Lee had emerged as the unlikely champion, and went on to earn a gold medal in the individual all-around competition in Tokyo.\n\nJoining Biles and Lee are Jordan Chiles, Jade Carey, and 16-year-old newcomer Hezly Rivera.\n\nNow, with Biles in top form and the team united in its goal of \"redemption,\" the women's squad is the favorite to win gold. And especially so, given that Russia, the defending gold medalist, won't be there. The IOC plans to allow only some Russian athletes to compete as \"individual neutral athletes\" under strict conditions it set in response to Russia's war in Ukraine. The country's absence also improves the men's chances of medaling in a sport normally dominated by Russia, China and Japan.\n\nEntering her fourth Olympics, Katie Ledecky continues to dominate the 800- and 1,500-meter freestyle events, in both of which she still holds the world records. Seven of her Olympic medals are gold, putting her just two wins away from earning the most Olympic gold medals of any female athlete in history. Younger swimmers have Ledecky beat in the 400-meter freestyle: Australia's Ariarne Titmus (who took gold in Tokyo and also reigns in the 200-meter event) and Canada's Summer McIntosh have each knocked down Ledecky's world record, which Titmus currently holds. The Titmus-McIntosh-Ledecky 400-meter race should make for a thrilling watch.\n\nIn men's swimming, the U.S. is looking for a superstar and hoping that Caeleb Dressel is it. The 27-year-old won five gold medals in Tokyo -- joining an elite few of swimmers that have won that many in a single Games, including Michael Phelps and Mark Spitz. After taking an eight-month break from the sport, Dressel showed at the Olympic trials last month that he's still fast in sprints.\n\nHeading into Paris, however, the two fastest swimmers in the world are not from the usual rival powerhouses (Australia and the U.S.) but from Canada -- McIntosh on the women's -- and France -- L\u00e9on Marchand.\n\nA doping scandal sparked international outrage after it was revealed in April that 32 Chinese swimmers tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug ahead of the Tokyo Games in 2021 but were cleared to compete. The drug in question -- called trimetazidine or TMZ -- is the same one found in a sample from Kamila Valieva, the Russian figure skater who was subsequently slapped with a four-year ban from international competition.\n\nChinese officials say an unintentional contamination led to the positive tests. The World Anti-Doping Agency accepted that explanation after its investigation and said that international doping rules don't require them to ban the athletes.\n\nThe U.S. Justice Department has opened a criminal probe into the case involving the swimmers. Meanwhile, China is expected to send 11 of the 32 swimmers who had the performance drug in their system in 2021 to compete in Paris.\n\nThe agency's handling of the positive tests has sowed doubt deeper among critics who question whether the regulatory body responsible for curbing cheating holds some countries to a lower standard than others.\n\nThe 100-meter sprint, the most popular track event, has shaped up to be a familiar two-nation race. Representing Jamaica in the women's race is Shericka Jackson, whose biggest challenge is American Sha'Carri Richardson. But don't overlook Jamaican sprint queen Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, who will race in her fifth and final Olympics 16 years after becoming the first Caribbean woman to win the 100-meter gold. They are chasing Florence Griffith Joyner's record set in 1988.\n\nIn the 200-meter, there's a real chance we could see the fall of Flo-Jo's world record set that same year when she ran 21.34 seconds. Jackson will go head-to-head with teammate Elaine Thompson-Herah and Gabby Thomas of Team USA.\n\nIn the men's 100-meter race, Noah Lyles on Team USA will face Jamaica's Oblique Seville and Kishane Thompson, each aiming to break the world record time set by eight-time Olympic gold medalist Usain Bolt. Still, the field is brimming with talent that clouds podium predictions. Other top contenders include reigning Olympic champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and a former world champion American Fred Kerley.\n\nLyles also racing in the 200-meter -- his better event -- a race that won't be as wide open as the 100. He's the favorite, ahead of Tebogo, a notable exception to the rivalry who won the men's race last week at an international meet in Monaco.\n\nSoccer starts before the Games officially kick off with the opening ceremony. The U.S. women's national team is aiming to upgrade their bronze medal from Tokyo. The four-time gold medalists haven't taken first on the podium since the 2012 Games in London. Since the retirement of major stars -- Megan Rapinoe, Carli Lloyd, Julie Ertz, Sam Mewis -- has made way for a younger team, which will be led by new head coach Emma Hayes, former manager of the women's Chelsea Football Club. World Cup champion Spain is the favorite to take gold.\n\nThe last time the U.S. sent a men's soccer team to the Olympics was in 2008, and they haven't medaled since 1904. Since the rule to restrict the competition to players under 23 went into effect in 1992, the men's team has advanced to the knockout stage only once.\n\nThe men kick off their tournament on Wednesday in a game against host country France, a favorite to win it all. The women's squad plays Zambia on Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "bpr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "bpr.org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
